div.p: AS IT WAS ACTED by her Maiesties Seruants at the Priuate house in Drury Lane.
LONDON, Printed by E. A. for Francis Constable, and are to be sold at his shop in Pauls Church-yard, at the signe of the Crane. 1631.

div.head: TO THE TRVLY NOBLE GENTLEMAN, WILLIAM TRESHAM Esquire.
div.p:
SIr, I have long cherished a desire, by some worthy testimony, to expresse how much I honour you: But after a tedious expectation, hopelesse to meete with an occasion to make me so fortunate; I resolued, rather then to hazard the censure of neglect, to snatch any opportunity of presenting my seruices. This (which to me hath no name, but what your bounty shall bestow) hauing pleased you vpon
the Stage, comming into the world, offereth it selfe to kisse your hand. If you be merciful, I am vpon euen termes with the world beside, and will study next to reach your minde with imaginations of a higher nature. In the meane time, grow you vp, and ripen your selfe for Honour; the flowings of your blood will instruct you how to merit; while I rest content with my ambition, if I may still write my selfe,

div.head: THE SCHOOLE OF COMPLEMENT.
PROLOGVE.
div.l: IT is a principle by Nature wrot
In all our vnderstanding, there is not end.
One Art or action, but it must tend
And moue from some beginning to its
The Souldiers that weare the honoured bayes
Vpon their browes, and glorious Trophies raise
To fame on pile of wounds, knew a time when
They suckt at warre. Your Muse inspired men
And of diuiner earth, sacred for wit,
Crept out of their first elements to it:
The goodliest Haruest had first seed and hope,
Ere it could lade with an enriching crop
The rurall Teame, th'exactest building first
Grew from a stone, though afterward it durst
Wrap his faire head in clouds: nothing so true,
As all things haue beginning: vpon you
Dwell candid application; this Play is
The first fruits of a Muse, that before this
Neuer saluted Audience, nor doth meane,
To sweare himselfe a Factor for the Scene.
Though he employ some houres he onely prayes
You take it as first borne, although he sayes,
He meant it not his heire, since tis vniust
One should haue all, as in the Law it must.
Accept then a beginning; all men know,
He first kist bayes, that wore them on his brow.

list.head: Drammatis Personae.
list.item: Infortunio, a Gentleman louer of Selina.
Antonio, son to Cornelio, in loue with Hilaria.
Gasparo, a Gentleman a Louer of Felice.
Bubulcus, a rich Gull, in loue with Hilaria.

sp.speaker: Antonio.
sp.p: SIrra, this Welshman is in loue with my sister Selina, and hath chosen me for his Prolocutor.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: O! this Loue will make vs all mad, thou knowest I lou'd a sister of thine once, but heauen knowes where she is, I thinke she lou'd me too, dost thinke she did not?

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: Well, thy father has reason to curse himselfe, beside some that she and I haue.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Nay, nay, thou't fall into passion againe, when things are past recouery, 'twas a good wench, but come, prethee leaue to thinke on her.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: Nay, I ha done, what shal's doe?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Any thing but talke of State matters: thou hast much intelligence in the world, prethee whats the newes abroad? I come forth a purpose to heare some, and this is an age of nouelties.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: Newes? O excellent newes!

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Prethee what ist? I long to heare some.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: There is no newes at all.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Call you that excellent newes?

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: Is it not good newes, that there is no bad newes? the truth is, the newes-maker Master Money-lacke is sicke of a consumption of the wit.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: The newes-maker? why, is there any newes-maker?

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: Oh sir, how should younger brothers haue maintained themselues, that haue trauelled, and haue the names of Countreyes, and Captaines without booke, as perfect as their prayers, I and perfecter too? for I thinke there is more probability of forgetting their prayers, they say them so seldome; I tell you sir, I haue knowne a Gentleman that has spent the best part of a thousand pound, while he was prentice to the trade in Holland, and out of three sheetes of paper, which was his whole stocke, a pen and inke-horne he borrowed, hee set vp shop, and spent a hundred pound a yeere vpon his whore, and found sheetes for them both to lye in too: it has beene a great profession; mary most commonly they are Souldiers: a peace concluded, is a great plague vnto 'em, and if the warres hold, we shall haue store of them; O, they are men worthy of commendations, they speake in print.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Are they Souldiers?

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p:
Faith so they would be thought, though indeed they are but mungrels, not worthy of that noble attribute; they are indeed bastards, not sonnes of warre and true Souldiers, whose diuine soules I honour, yet they may be cald great spirits too, for their valour is inuisible, these I say will write you a battell in any part of Europe at an houres warning, and yet neuer set foot out of a Tauerne, describe you Towns, Fortifications, Leaders, the strength a'th enemies, what Confederates, euery dayes march, not a Souldier shall lose a haire, or haue a bullet fly betweene
his Armes, but hee shall haue a Page to waite on him in quarto, nothing destroyes 'em but want of a good memory, for if they escape contradiction, they may be chronicled.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Why, thou art wise enough to be an Informer.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: I mary, now you speake of a Trade indeed, the very Atlas of a State Politicke, the Common-shore of a City, nothing falls amisse vnto 'em, and if there bee no filth in the Common-wealth can liue by honesty, and yet be knaues by their priuiledge, there is not an oath but they will haue money for it!

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Oh braue Trade.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: They can eat men aliue and digest 'em, they haue their conscience in a string, and can stifle it at their pleasure, the Deuils iourneymen, set vp for themselues, and keepe a damnation house of their owne; indeed they seldome proue Aldermen, yet they are taken for Knights euery day a'th weeke, when they ride post, they haue the art of insinuation, and speake writs familiarly, they are Agents as I haue heard for the Deuill in their life time, and if they dye in their bed, haue this priuiledge, to be sonnes of hell by adoption, and take place of Seriants.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: Stay. Who's there? thy sister and Infortunio: let's obserue.

sp.speaker: Infor.
sp.p: I must haue other answer, for I must loue you.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Must? but I doe not see any necessity that I should loue you, I doe confesse you are a proper man.

sp.speaker: Infor.
sp.l: O doe not mocke Selina, let not excellence
Which you are full of, make you proud and scornefull,
I am a Gentleman, though my outward part
Cannot attract affection, yet some haue told me,
Nature hath made me what she need not shame,
Yet looke into my heart, there you shall see
What you cannot despise, for there you are
With all your graces waiting on you, there
Loue hath made you a Throne to sit, and rule
Ore Infortunio, all my thoughts obeying
And honouring you as Queene, passe by my outside:
My brest I dare compare with any man.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: 〈…〉 can see this brest you boast of so?

sp.speaker: Infor.
sp.l: Oh t'tis an easie worke, for though it be
Not to be pearced by the dull eye, whose beame
Is spent on outward shapes, there is a way
To make a search into hiddenst passage.
I know you would not loue to please your sense:
A Tree that beares a ragged vnleau'd top
In depth of Winter, may when Summer comes
Speake by his fruit, he is not dead but youthfull,
Though once he shew'd no sap: my heart's a plant
Kept downe by colder thoughts, and doubtfull feares,
Your frownes like Winter stormes make it seeme dead,
But yet it is not so, make it but yours,
And you shall see it spring, and shoot forth leaues
Worthy your eye, and the oppressed sap
Ascend to euery part to make it greene,
And pay your loue with fruit when Haruest comes.
If my affection be suspected, make
Experience of my loyalty, by some seruice
Though full of danger, you shall know me better,
And so discerne the truth of what you see not.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Then you confesse your loue is cold as yet,
And Winter's in you heart.

sp.speaker: Infor.
sp.l: Mistake me not, Silena, for I say
My heart is cold, not loue.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: And yet your loue is from your heart Ile warrant.

sp.speaker: Infor.
sp.l: Oh you are nimble to mistake,
My heart is cold in your displeasures onely,
And yet my loue is feruent, for your eye
Casting out beames, maintaines the flame it burnes in.
Againe, sweete Loue,
My heart is not mine owne, 'tis yours, you haue it,
And while it naked lyes, not dain'd your bosome
To keepe it warme, how can it be but cold,
In danger to be frozen? blame not it,
You onely are in fault it hath no heate.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Well sir, I know you haue Rethoricke, but I
Can without art giue you a finall answer.

sp.speaker: Infor.
sp.l: Oh stay, and thinke a while, I cannot relish
You should say finall, sweet, deliberate,
It doth concerne all the estate I haue,
I meane not dunghill treasure, but my life
Doth stand or fall to it, if your answer be
That you can loue me, be it swift as lightning,
But if you meane to kill me, and reiect
My so long loue-deuotions, which I haue pay'd
As to an Altar, stay a little longer,
And let me count the riches I shall lose
By one poore aëry word, first giue me backe
That part of Infortunio that is lost
Within your loue, play not the Tyrant with me.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Y'are ouer-weake to let your passions sway you:
If I knew any thing I had of yours,
I would not doe you that iniustice, sir,
To let it stay with me, and for your loue
I cannot pay it backe againe with mine,
Either release the debt, or I shall dye in't,
Your suite is fruitlesse, hopelesse, pardon me, farewell.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Now by all my hopes you are to blame, sister, come, this Gentleman deserues your loue, Infortunio.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: Brother, you forget your selfe.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Why, I doe remember I am your brother, I say you must loue him.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: Must?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: What, does that moue your spirit? what are you, but you may loue? be not petulant, y'are a baggage and not worthy of a man, by heauen I now could kick her.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: Thy tother sister was of calmer temper, this a true woman.

sp.speaker: Infor.
sp.p: Sir, had not nature made you brother to her, I should be angry.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Alas poore Gentleman, I doe not feele my selfe in such an humour for Hilaria, and yet by this hand I loue her well enough, and now I thinke on't, I promis'd her my company, she has a damnable vsurious stinking wretch to her father, that cannot abide me, but 'tis no matter, this wench and I may find a place to meete in, in spight of his eyes and spectacles. How now Gorgon, what sayes she?

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.p: Sir, I haue done your remembrances to Mistris Hilaria, and told her you should find her comming by and by, but you were best passe in some obscurity, for her father Rufaldo is hard by sir. Lupus in Fabula.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Gasparo, and thou loue me, shew thy wit to entertaine this piece of blacke Dammaske and Veluet guards, while I goe in to Hilaria.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: Old men are the truest louers, young men are inconstant and wag with euery wind, we neuer moue, but are as true as steele.

sp.speaker: Gor.
sp.p: But in womens matters as weake as water, as weake as water.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: Besides, sweet Loue, but doe I court a shadow? to see whither loue will carry a man: let me see, I could find in my heart to bestow a ring vpon my Sweet-heart, but that I am loth to part with it: hem, I will get but one childe, and that shall be a boy, lest hauing too many children, I vndoe my heire, and my goods be deuided. O sweet Selina, O amiable Selina; sure I am not old.

sp.speaker: Gor.
sp.p: I haue it, Signior Gasparo, pray let me begin with my Merchant if you loue me, and if you like it, second me.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: Goe to Gorgon, let's see thy window.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p:
Old men walke with a staffe, and creepe along the
streets, hold their heads below their girdle, faulter in their speech, foame at mouth, and breathe ten times in a furlong, and are ready to spit their lungs on euery mans threshold.

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.p: God saue you sir.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: God a mercy honest Gorgon.

sp.speaker: Gor.
sp.p: I crie you mercie sir, Ile assure you sir, I tooke you for Master Rufaldo the old Merchant.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: Why, and am not I? is not the fellow drunke? I am Rufaldo.

sp.speaker: Gor.
sp.p: It may be some kin to him, but not that Rufaldo I meane, you are younger a faire deale.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: I am that Rufaldo, the Merchant, that buried my wife lately, and haue one daughter Hilaria, ancient acquaintance with Cornelio and your Master Antonio.

sp.speaker: Gor.
sp.p: Oh sir, you must excuse me for that.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: Is thy name Gorgon?

sp.speaker: Gor.
sp.p: What else sir, honest Gorgon I?

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: Doe I know thee to be Gorgon? what, shall I be fac'd out of my selfe? why thou varlet, who am I, if not Rufaldo?

sp.speaker: Gor.
sp.p: Why sir, 'tis plaine, you haue no gray haires in your head, your cheeke is scarlet, a wanton youthfull eye; Rufaldo had a head like frost, his eyes sunke into his hollows, a rugged brow, a hoarie beard, and all his body not worth a drop of blood, a very crazie old meale-mouth'd Gentleman, you are younger at least by thirty yeeres.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: Ile assure thee I was Rufaldo, when I rose in the morning.

sp.speaker: Gor.
sp.p: You haue not slept since, haue you?

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Gor.
sp.p: 'Tis the more strange. I haue heard of some that haue beene changed in a dreame, but neuer waking before: this is strange, nay admirable!

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: Young, chang'd, art sure thou dost not mocke?

sp.speaker: Gor.
sp.p:
I were a very knaue then, if you be Rufaldo, I hope
your worship knowes I haue beene bound to my good behauiour.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: Altered young, ha! I would I were; and yet me thinks I am liuelier then I was, I feele my ioynts plyable as waxe, and my voyce is stronger too. But tell me, honest Gorgon, is it possible for an old man to be young againe?

sp.speaker: Gor.
sp.p: Nay, I see youle not beleeue me: well sir, I will be bold to report the wonder abroad, and astonish all your friends.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: Nay, stay, honest Gorgon, ha! young, no gray haires? stay, who's here?

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: Ha! 'tis not he, Ile speake to him, no 'tis in vaine, Ile see if he knowes me.— He passes by.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: Gasparo! what, does not he know me too?

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: Sir, I should know you, are you not Signior Petrucchio, the dancing Master?

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: Tricks, passages, I am Rufaldo, old Rufaldo.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: Rufaldo indeed is old, but you are young, you doe retaine his countenance, I would sweare you were he, but you are younger farre.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: 'Tis so, I am chang'd, I am younger then I was, I am that Rufaldo, beleeue, I know you to be a learned Gentleman, nam'd Gasparo, I was told afore I was altered, but not to trouble you with many questions, onely one, Gasparo, is it a thing possible for an old man to be young againe? I know 'tis admirable, but is it possible? you are a Scholler.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: Possible? oh yes, there's no question, for we see by experience, Stagges cast their old hornes, and proue vigorous, Snakes cast off their old coates, Eagles renew their age, your plants doe it familiarly, the Phoenix when she is old, burnes herselfe to ashes, from thence reuiues a young Phoenix againe. Possible? I haue heard some old men haue beene twice children sir,— therefore 'this not impossible.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: Tis very strange: I am not yet confident.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: There be receites in Physicke, sir, to keepe them young, sauing that time runnes on a little beforehand with em: yes, and to make young, since it is harder to make aliue when they are dead, then to make young when they are aliue, and Physicke doth reuiue some out of all question, though not so familiarly as kill, for that they doe with a little study; mary I thinke, if it were as gainefull to the Phisicion to restore as to destroy, hee would practise the Art of recouery very faithfully.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: Why, doe you thinke it would not proue as gainefull?

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: Oh! by no meanes, for where an old man would giue a hundred pound, to haue forty or fifty yeeres wiped off the old score of his life, his wife or next heire would ioyne rather then faile, to out-bid him halfe on't, to put him out of debt quite, and to send his old leaking vessell into mare mortuum.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: Well, well, but if I bee young, I haue tooke no Physicke for't.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: If nay, 'tis past if, and, and too, you are certainly restor'd, let me see, you looke like one of foure, or sixe and thirty, not a minute aboue, and so much a man may take you for.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: Well, I know not what to say too't, there is some power in loue has blest me: now Selina, be thou gracious.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: Are you in loue? nay, the wóder is not so great; who can expresse the power of Loue? I haue read of a Painter named Pigmalion, that made the Picture of a woman so to the life, that he fell in loue with it, courted it, lay in bed with it, and by power of Loue, it became a soft-natur'd wench indeed, and he begot I know not how many children of her. Well sir, Selina cannot choose but be mad for you.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: Not mad, Gasparo, I would be loth to be troubled with her and she be mad.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p:
Yes, and shee be mad in loue, there is no harme in't, she cannot be too mad in loue, your Cornucopia may be
abated at pleasure, besides sir, the best morall men say, Loue it selfe is a madnesse, and the madder your wife is, the more sure you may be she loues you.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: No, no, I loue no madnesse on any condition, for feare of being horne-mad.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: Why sir, madnesse is not such a discredit, as the age goes: you know there are many mad fashions, and what man but some times may be mad? are not your great men mad, that when they haue enough, will pawne their soule for a Monopolie? besides mad Lords, what doe you thinke of Ladies at some time of the Moone, you may spell em in their names, Maddame? you haue mad Courtiers, that run madding after Citizens wiues: the Citizens are mad too, to trust em with their wares, who haue beene so deepe in their wiues bookes before: your Iustice of Peace is some times mad too, for when he may see well enough, he will suffer any man to put out his eye with a bribe: some Lawyers are often starke-mad, and talke wildly, no man is able to endure their Tearmes.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: Prethee mad-cap leaue, I am almost mad to heare thee.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: Well, my old young Rufaldo, if you marry Selina, I shall haue a paire of gloues, I hope, and youle let mee dance at your wedding.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: That thou shalt, boy, and Ile dance my selfe too, hey,—

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: Farewell credulitie; ha, ha, with what a greedinesse doe old men run out of their wits? 'Twas a good recreation to see with what pleasure he suffered himselfe to be guld: faith Gasparo, play out thy hand, now thou art in: me thinkes I haue an excellent appetite to make my selfe merry with the simplicity of this age: let me see, 'tis Spring and, I meane to giue my head a purgation, it may beate off the remembrance of my lost Loue Felice: a pox of Melancholy, I will act two or three parts if I liue in spight of it, and if I die then

sp.speaker: Gor.
sp.p: Seignior Gasparo, my Master would speake with you: the proiect too: I met the Youth strutting like a Gentleman Vsher, 'twas my inuention.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: But I gaue it pollish, Gorgon.

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.p: I confesse, you tooke off the rough-cast, but 'twas Gorgons head brought forth the proiect, from my Ioues braine came this Minerua.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: I thinke thou art a wit.

sp.speaker: Gor.
sp.p: Who, I a wit? I thought you had 'more wit, then to make such a question, all the Towne takes me for a wit, heres a pate hath crakers in't and flashes.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: And thou saist the word, weele ioyne in a proiect of wit, to make an Asse of the world a little, it shall make vs merry, if it take no other wayes, wo't ioyne?

sp.speaker: Gor.
sp.p: By this hand, any proiect of wit, what ist, good Gasparo? the proiect.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: Canst be close?

sp.speaker: Gor.
sp.p: As mid-night to a Bawd, or a paire of Trusses to an Irish mans buttockes.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: Goe to, thou shalt now then excuse me to thy Master, I will presently furnish my selfe with new lodgings, and expect to heare from me shortly my braue Delphicke, I haue it in Embrio, and I shall soone be deliuered.

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.p: If I faile, call me Spider-catcher.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: Mum, not a word, if all hit right, we may Laugh all our melancholy thoughts away.

div.head: Actus secundus, Scena prima.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p:
If I were a woman, now could I fall in loue with my selfe: euery body tels me I am the proprest Gentleman in the Towne, and I put it vp, for the truth is, I dare not giue any one the lye, a pox a fighting, I can looke as big
as another, but shall I be such an Asse, to venture my selfe with beasts? for they say, your swords most commonly are Foxes, and haue notable mettall in'em; let me see, I am now at Rufaldoes my father in Law that must be, here he is.

div.p: Master Rufaldo, if you had beene my owne father, as you are but like to be my father in Law, I should haue prou'd my selfe a foole, by this hand I should not haue knowne you, why, how briske and neate, and youthfull he is!

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: I am something altered I confesse, since I saw you.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: By this flesh that shines, a man would not take you to be aboue fiue or sixe and thirty at most, how came this?

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: Iust as Gasparo told me, 'tis apparent, nay, nay, sonne, forbeare to be inquisitiue, I confesse I am abated of my age, the power of Loue, and so forth, but I see your fire of loue is not out too.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: No, mine was but raked vp in the embers.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: Why, this Loue does make vs all ingenious too: come sit downe, sauing your tayle sir, a cushion, we may discourse with the more case.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Pray, how does my Sweet-heart Mistris Hillaria.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: Shee is very well, ha sonne, I am in loue too: son I call you, I hope you will get my daughters good-will, but youle finde her peeuish.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: No matter, sir, for that, I would not haue her easily, I would sweat for her, Ile warrant, Ile make her loue me.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: Looke you can you read, I made a ditty to send to my Mistris, and my Musician that I keepe in my house, to teach my daughter, hath set it to a very good aire, he tels me: you shall heare and iudge of it, I heare him tuning his Instrument.

lg.l: God of Warre to Cupid yeeld,
He is Master of the field,
He with Arrow hits the heart,
Thou with Lance the worser part.
Cupid greater is then Ioue,
Since he wounded was with loue,
Nay, in power by much ods
He excels the other gods.
Loue transform'd Ioue to a Swan,
Made Vlysses a mad man,
But Rufaldo it does make
Young for his Selinas sake.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: How doe you relish it, ha?

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: I troth the Ditty is as pretty an ayer as ere I saw, 'tis diuided into three regions too, I warrant you, can make Ballads easily.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: Oh fie, they are barbarous and ignoble, that's beggerly.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: But for all that, I haue read good stuffe sometimes, especially in your fighting Ballads, When Cannons are roaring, and bullets are flying, &c.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: Fie, a whipping post, tinkerly stuffe; how did you like the aire?

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: As sweet an aire as a man would wish to liue in, but 'tis some-what backeward.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: Oh Musicke, the life of the soule.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: I should haue learn'd Musicke once too, but my Master had so many crochets, I could ne'r away with it: but where is your daughter, sir? there is no Musicke without her, she is the best Instrument to play vpon.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: And you shall haue her betweene your legs presently.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: I had as liefe be betwixt hers, for all that.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: Hilaria, where is this girle? Ile fetch her to you, and leaue her with you, for I haue a Loue of mine owne, to whom I meane in person to present this Ditty, Ile fetch her.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: I doe not see what fault shee'can finde with me, and if I had some good word to come ouer her: but I must helpe it out and neede be, with swearing; but here she is.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: Still Antonio with you? you are a foolish girle: doe I take care to prouide a husband for you? and will you cast away your selfe vpon a Prodigall? but that I would not discontent his sister, whom I hope to make my wife, I would forbid him my house; therefore be wise, and take heede of him, hee's giddy-headed, and loose-bodied. The Bee may buzze, but he will leaue a sting: plant your loue there: vpon my blessing, he has many Lordships.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Pray heauen he haue good manners.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: I haue set open the gate of opportunity; Cupid speed vs both.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Let mee alone to enter my man, now the point is open: hum, stay, there's a man in her Tables more then I looked for: foot, he kisses her, Ile call Rufaldo backe, hees out of sight, it were but a cowardly tricke, for me to run-away.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Be Buzzard now, the sting of conscience eate vp his gut, frie his suet, and leaue him at his death not able to weigh downe a pound of candle.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: He talkes of suet, I doe melt already.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Looke, doe you see that man of clothes? vpon my fathers blessing he must be my husband. What will you doe?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Fight with him, his clothes are too big for him, Ile beate him till he swell to 'em.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: No, as you loue me, doe not strike him.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: I will set a good face whatsoeuer come. Hilaria, how does my Loue, come kisse: why so: this comes of valour, we fall to, and he falls off, he's some coward, I hope, and how doest Hilaria? 'tis an age since I saw thee: what Springals is that? ha.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: One that desires to be of your acquaintance, sir.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: My acquaintace, who is he? none but Knights, and Knights fellowes, are of my acquaintance, I scorne Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Hi.
sp.p: But for my sake, pray be acquainted with him.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Thou shalt doe much with me, sir, I am content for her sake whom I loue, to bee acquainted with you, wo't borrow any money? for so doe all that begin their acquaintance with me, 'tis the fashion, he is a coward, is he not? here: nay, and you scorne my money, I scorne your acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Pray for my sake.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Why, he will borrow no money of mee, I had neuer such a tricke put vpon me, since I knew what acquaintance was: Ime sure there haue beene forty acquainted with me, since I came to Towne, and not one had not so little breeding, to let me aske 'em the question, wee could no sooner shake hands, but the other was in my pocket: It may be 'tis his modesty. Sir, this is my Loue Hilaria, and if you will not borrow money of me, by this hand, there lyes my sword, he is a coward.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: It appeares.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Hilaria is my Mistresse, and if any man dare be so venturous, as to blast her reputation with a foule breath, he shall breathe his last.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: 'Tis very sure, he shall not be immortall.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Or if you shall offer in my presence to defile her lip, or touch her hand, or kisse but the nether part of her vesture, you had better kisse her in another place; nay doe but blow on her.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: You forget your selfe, this is my friend.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Or winke at her, or speake to her, or make signes, or thinke on her to my face, and you had better keepe your thoughts to your selfe: now to conclude, and if you bee agrieu'd, my name is Bubulcus, and you lye.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: And you lye there ath ground: why should not I knocke his braines out with his owne hilts, or stake him to the ground, like a man that had hang'd himselfe? Sirra clothes, Rat of Nilus fiction, monster, golden Calfe, oh, I would kicke thee till thou hast no more braines, then thy cousin Woodcocke: I will not dishonour my selfe to kill thee, halfe a dozen kickes will be as good as a house of correction, out you Monkey.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Oh, that I could run thee thorow body and soule, I will challenge thee, a pox on your toes, would I had the paring of your nayles, were you dumbe so long for this?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Hence.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Who look't for you? when will you be here agen? looke for a challenge, the time may come, when I will beate thee.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Has thy father left a multitude of men, to make choice of this peece of folly to be thy husband? oh, the blindnesse of a couetous wretched father, that is led onely by the eares, and in loue with sounds! Nature had done wel to haue thrust him into the world without an eye, that like a Mole is so affected to base earth, and there meanes to dig for Paradise: but come, Hilaria. Fathers their children, and themselues abuse, That wealth a husband for their daughter chuse.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: I did not thinke, Rufaldo, pardon me,
You could haue so preuail'd, but if she can
Plant her affection on yee, Ile not be
Backward to call you sonne.

sp.speaker: Seli.
sp.l: Hee does appeare
With all the charmes of loue vpon his eye,
And not rough drawne, but polisht, he assumes
A power 'boue all resistance.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: An old mans Darling, is a petty Queene
Aboue all her desires.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.l: Nay, she shall want nothing my wealth can purchase,
O my sweet Selina.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Rufaldo, with your patience, I would haue
A word or two in priuate, you neede not
Preiudicate me.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.l: With all my heart.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Selina, thou knowest I am thy father.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: My duty, sir, shall speake it.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: And you know whom you haue reiected.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Young Infortunio.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Aud you know what man he is, with whom
You meane to tye that knot, nothing but
Death is able to vndoe.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Rufaldo, sir, an old man.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Oh Selina, Felice thy poore sister thou recalst
To sad remembrance, but heauen alas
Knowes onely where she is.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Sir, I haue often heard you talke of her,
But neuer knew that sister well.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Thou with thy vncles tendernesse wast kept
Alwayes ith Countrey, not vntill her losse
At home with me, her fate taught me to giue
A liberty to thee, her I restrain'd
Poore wench in loue with Gasparo, till betwixt
Obedience to a father, and the loue
To him, she left vs both, father and friend,
Now to auoyd the like affliction,
I vowed thy freedome, and thou seest I doe
Not encounter thy affection with the bonds
A father might enforce vpon his child.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: I humbly thanke you.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: But yet Selina,
Take heed, be not too rash, I haue obseru'd
You want no common iudgement, O doe not
Precipitate thy selfe into a sorrow,
Shall waste thee with repentance, let me tell you,
There is a methode, when your passion's young
To keepe it in obedience: you loue Rufaldo,
Art thou not young? How will the Rose agree
With a dead Hyacinth? or the Honey Wood-bind,
Circling a withered Bryer?
You can apply, can you submit your body
To bed with Ice and Snow, your blood to mingle?
Would you be deaf'd with coughing, teach your eye
How to be rumaticke? Breathes he not out
His body in diseases, and like dust
Falling all into pieces, as if Nature
Would make him his old graue: I say too much.
O what are all the riches of the world,
To an oppressed mind? which then must be
Fed with despaire of change, or will gold
Buy off th' imprisonment? nay, will it not
Compose the chaines, that bind you to endure it?
Well I haue said enough, keepe still your freedome,
And loose it where you will, you shall not blame
Me for your fate, nor grieue me with your shame.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Deare father, low as earth I tender you
The duty of a daughter, I haue heard you
Not with a carelesse eare, that liberty
You haue bestow'd on me, for which I owe
All that I am, doth make me confident
You will not be offended, if I tell you
My loue is vertuous, were it otherwise,
I should elect as you premonish youth,
And prodigall blood: And father, I thinke here
I shew my selfe your daughter, nor am I
Without good president too: how many fine
Young noble Ladies, in this Faiëry Ile,
Haue matcht with reuerend age? and liue as they
Were borne from Natures puritie, free from staine
Of sensuall imputation, by their Loues,
Deriuing heauenly honours to themselues
'Boue merit of equality.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: No more, heauens blessing and mine
Light on thee, sha't haue Rufaldo.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: I would not leaue Rufaldo for a world
Of rash vntemperate youth, beleeue it sir.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Rufaldo, heard you that? she sayes she would not
Leaue you for a world of other men.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.l: Nor I for thousand worlds forsake my Loue.
Come seale it with a kisse, another, another, another.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: As close as Cockles.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.l: Oh, that we were married! 'tis death to stay the
Ceremonies, would we were a bed together.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: 'Twere time I see we were at conference,
To confirme all things for the marriage,
You being agreed, I thinke we shall not differ
In other circumstance, and 'twere sinne to let
That keepe your ioyes asunder by delay:
Please you weele haue some treaties.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.l: Most willingly, O my bird, my Chicke, my Doue,
My America, my new-found world, I shall shortly
Run backe into one and twenty againe.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: With what agility he moues himselfe,
As he were made of ayre? let weaknes taxe
Our inequality, I haue a minde
Can easily contemne what the worlds malice
Out of its owne first guiltines can throw
Vpon our loues, 't shall be enough for me
Thus to conuince the world of so much basenes,
Lodg'd in luxurious thoughts, by my chast thoughts.
Rufaldo, thou art mine, all time, me thinkes
Is slow, till we be actually possest
Of mutuall enioying. Stay, who's this
sp.stage: Enter lenkin, and his Page locarello.
sp.l: The Welshman that deliuers his affection
At second hand to me.

sp.speaker: Ien.
sp.p: Looke you Pages, where our Sweet-hearts and Pigsnies be, & her could tell what to say to her now, know her heart very well, but pogs vpon her, cannot aule her knowledge speake Rethoricks, and Oratories, and fine words to her? looke you kanow better to fight, and cut doublets with her Welsh glaues, marke you.

sp.speaker: Ioc.
sp.p: Sir will you loose this opportunitie, youle curse your selfe in Welsh, two or three dayes together for't.

sp.speaker: Ien.
sp.p: Sentilwoman, if her knaw not her name, was Ienkin, borne in Wales, came of pig houses, & prittish bloods was haue great hils and mountaines aule her owne, when was get 'em againe, anie was her cousins, and our Countreyman was neuer conquered, but alwayes haue the victories prauely, haue her Armes and scushrins, to know that say you, was giue in her crests great deale of monsters, and Dragons, kille 'em with their hookes very valiantly, as any Sentelman in the whole world: pray you now was please you place her affections and goodwils vpon her, in wayes of makemoney, marke you teale plainely, lenkin was loue her very honestly, else pox vpon her, and her will fight in her cause, and quarrels, long as haue any plood in her bellies and backs too, marke you.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Sir, I am bound to you for the affection
You cast on me, 'tis farre aboue my merit.

sp.speaker: Ien.
sp.p: Merits say you? awle merits are awle banished our Countries and Nations, you know dat: pray you was her loue lenkin?

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Loue you, sir? I know not
How to be so inhumane, not to loue you,
Your parts deserue a nobler obiect, I am not
Worthy so much opinion of your loue,
But wherein I may doe you seruice sir,
You shall command Selina.

sp.speaker: Ien.
sp.p: Shall her, was make her meanes and satisfactions warrant her, or say Senkin was Sentleman of Wales, say you now Pages, was haue her matrimonies & wedlocks very fast, looke you, and when was get her awse her cousins, was make ioyes and gratulation for her good fortunes vpon her walsh Harpes, know you dat very well Pages? her feare her shall be Knighted one dayes, and haue great cumulations of vrships, honours, and dignities too, a great while agoe.

sp.speaker: Ioc.
sp.p: And great Castles ith' aire.

sp.speaker: Ien.
sp.p: Was giue awle our lands, and craggy Tenements in Wales away to our cousin vp Iohn, and liue her selfe here vpon very good fashions, with our monies and mighty riches, when her can get 'em.

sp.speaker: Infor.
sp.p: How now, whither so fast, man? thou maist get to hell by night, and thou goest but an Aldermans pace.

sp.speaker: Ien.
sp.p: By Cats blood, her will goe to the Deuill and her list, what is that to her?

sp.speaker: Infor.
sp.p: Cry you mercy, your name is Master lenkin.

sp.speaker: Ien.
sp.p: And what haue her to say to Master lenkin? lenkin is as good names as her owne, pray you was good Sentle man as her selfe, know very well, say you now?

sp.speaker: Infor.
sp.p: Godboy, sir.

sp.speaker: Ien.
sp.p: Boyes, does her call her boyes? harke you her? her name is lenkin, her be no boyes, no shildren.

sp.speaker: Infor.
sp.p: I will not be vsed so.

sp.speaker: Ien.
sp.p: Her shall be vs'd worse, and her call lenkin boyes, was knocke as tall a man as herselfe, an welsh plood be vp, looke you.

sp.speaker: Infor.
sp.p: Can she loue Rufaldo? 'tis impossible.

sp.speaker: Ien.
sp.p: Piple pables, 'tis very possible.

sp.speaker: Infor.
sp.p: His body has more diseases then an Hospitall, an hunger-staru'd Rascall.

sp.speaker: Ien.
sp.p: Raskals? sheshu! was neuer such names and appellations put vpon her, awle her dayes, Becar her will make you eate vp awle her words and ignominies, or her plade shall make holes in your bellies diggon.

sp.speaker: Infor.
sp.p: A very puffe, a weake Canniball.

sp.speaker: Ien.
sp.p: Hey, puffe, and Cannibals, if the Deuill be in your mouthes, her will picke your teeths with her welsh plade, and pay you for all your puffes, & Cannibals, warrant her.

sp.speaker: Infor.
sp.l: But 'tis her fault, aloue impudent woman.
Oh, may you like Narcissus perish by
Your face, the fall of others, or vnpityed
Of heauen and earth, dye loathsome! I could curse.

sp.speaker: Ien.
sp.l: Her can curse, and sweare too, looke you now.

sp.speaker: Infor.
sp.l: Pardon diuinest sexe, passions doe force
My reason from me, I doe submit,
Craue pardon, as your creature.

sp.speaker: Ien.
sp.p: Nay, and her craue pardons, and make submissions, lenkin was put vp awle her angers and indignations, farewell.

sp.speaker: Infor.
sp.l: Oh, Selina!
Thou art too much an Adamant
To draw my soule vnto thee, either be
Softer, or lesse attractiue: but Rufaldo,
'Tis depth of witchcraft, oh, I could be mad,
Beyond all patience mad, it is some malice
Hath laid this poyson on her.

sp.speaker: Gor.
sp.p: Here's Infortunio. Alas, poore Gentleman, little does he thinke what blacke and white is here, a bitter handfull of commendations to him, my young Mistris is mad of the old Cockscombe, and will marry him almost without asking, I cannot tell but if shee doe not cuckold him, and make him crye cornes on his toes ere he dye, he has fooles fortune, for a wise man would be out of hope to auoyd it, he spies me.

sp.speaker: Inf.
sp.p: Whither running, Gorgon?

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.p: Not out of my wit, Sir, I haue a Letter from my yong Mistris Selina, must in all haste haue cleanely conueyance to old Rufaldo.

sp.speaker: Inf.
sp.p: Let me but see the directions. To my beloued friend Master Rufaldo: 'tis a lye, she was mistaken, it was I should owe this appellation, Ile not beleeue the superscription, 'tis a painted face, I'de see the heart on't.

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.p: I hope, sir, you will not throw open the sheet, and discouer my Mistris secrets? How he stares!

sp.speaker: Inf.
sp.p: If you loue me, and wish me constant, be your owne friend, and let our marriage day begin with the next morning: thine, mine. Oh Selina, she's mad. All woman-kinde is mad; and I am mad: whom shall I rend in pieces for my wrongs, and as with Atomes fill this poysned ayre, Rufaldo? Stay, is not she a creature rationall? oh no, there is no sparke of nature in her, all is sunke, lost for euer: stay, stay, see.

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.p: He has made a Taylors bill on't, torn't apieces ere it be discharg'd: What shall I doe?

sp.speaker: Inf.
sp.l: This is Medias brother torne in pieces,
And this the way where she with Iason flies,
Tom Colchos, come not neere 'em, see, looke,
That's an arme rent off.

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.l: This?

sp.speaker: Inf.
sp.l: And the hand beckens vs
To cry out murder.

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.l: Ile but hold it by the hand.

sp.speaker: Inf.
sp.l: That's a leg o'th boy.

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.l: This sir, a leg, it shall goe with me then.

sp.speaker: Inf.
sp.l: There, there 'tis, head and yellow curled locks,
His eyes are full of teares, now they doe stare,
To see where all his other members lye.

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.p: So I haue all his quarters, Ile presently, sir, get poles for 'em, and hang 'em vpon the Gates in their postures for you.

sp.speaker: Inf.
sp.l: But she and Iason are both slipt, and Argos is
Sayling home to Greece, see how the waues
Doe tosse the Vessell, and the windes conspire
To dash it 'gainst a Rocke, it rides vpon
A watery mountaine, and is hid in cloudes,
It cannot stay there, now, now, it tumbles,
Three fatham beneath Hell, let 'em goe,
Here comes the Father of Medea now,
Calling in vaine vnto the gods, and spies
His Sonnes limbes throwne about, in stead of flowers,
To his Daughters nuptials he does take 'em vp,
He knowes the face, and now he teares his haire,
And raues, and cryes Medea, poore old man,
Command a funerall pile for thy yong Childe,
And lay the pretty limbs on, from whose ashes
Shalt haue another Sonne i'th shape of Phoenix.
Shall I? excellent! Prepare a fire
All of sweet wood for my sweet boy, a fire, a fire.

div.head: Actus tertius, Scena prima.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p:
'Tis now early day: fie, what a long night hath this beene? the Sunne went drunke to bed the last night, and could not see to rise this morning: I could hardly winke, I am sure, loue kept me waking, and the expectation of this my wedding day did so caper in my braines, I thought of nothing but dancing the shaking of the sheets with my sweet-heart. It is certaine, I am yong euery body now tels me, so it did appeare by Selina's consenting so soone to loue, for when I had but broke the Ice of my affection, shee fell ouer head and eares in loue with me; was euer man so happy as I am? I doe feele, I doe feele my yeeres fall off, as the raine from a man that comes dropping in, I doe feele my selfe euery day grow yonger and yonger still: let me see, an
hundred yeeres hence, if I liue to 't, I shall be new out of my teenes, and running into yeeres of discretion agen: Well, I will now to Master Cornelios, and bid 'em good morrow with a noise of Musicions, and to see the very talking of musicke, how my heart leapes and dances, at my wedding already! I haue bespoke the Parson to marry vs, and haue promised a double fee for expedition. O now I am so proud of my Ioy, my feete doe not know what ground they stand on.

sp.speaker: Ien.
sp.p: Ienkin has risen very early this mornings, and beene in studies and contemplations, to make ditties and verses vpon her Mistris beauties and pulchritudes, but the Deuil's sure in these Poetries, they call it Furies and Raptures, look you, but Ienkins pate is almost mad, and yet her cannot awle her inuentions meete with these Furies and Raptures.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: Thus farre I haue past without discouery: the morning is auspicious to my flight. Selina, what an alteration hath a day made in thee, that to preuent thy so desired marriage, thou art thus lost in a masculine habit, and dost flie him? thou didst so much loue aged Rufaldo, in what a Lethargy wert thou falne, Selina?

sp.speaker: Ien.
sp.p: Iocarello, does her not name Selina? 'tis no very good manners to make interruptions, her will heare more, looke you.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Whither had reason so withdrawne it selfe?
I could not make distinction of a man,
From such a heape of age, aches and rheume:
Sure I was mad, and doth encrease my fury,
To thinke with what a violence I ran
To imbrace such rottennesse. O, my guilty soule
Doth feele the punishment of the iniury
I did to Infortunio of late,
Of whom as I despaire, so shall the world,
Euer to know againe haplesse Selina.
This is the morne the sacred Rites should tie
Me to Rufaldo, ripe in expectation,
But like Ixion he shall graspe a Cloud,
My empty cloathes at home, Selina thus
Is turn'd a Shepheard, and will try her fortune;
Hard by the Shepheards haue their shady dwellings,
There let Selina end her haplesse daies,
Father and all farewell. Thus as Felice
My other Sister, Ile weare out my life,
Farre from your knowledge: sacred loue commands
Reuenge and iustice for my cruelty,
And reson now awak'd shall lead me to it,
Thus I am safe, I goe to finde out that,
Will meete me euery where, a iust sad fate.

sp.speaker: Ien.
sp.p: Pages, haue her seene treames and apparitions: hark you, was Selina turn'd Shepheardesse, pray you?

sp.speaker: Ioc.
sp.p: Either we dreame, or this was Selina, your Mistris, that is turn'd into breeches, and become a Shepheard; the case is altered.

sp.speaker: Ien.
sp.p: What a teuill is in the matters & businesses, pray you? cases neuer was knowen such cases and alterations in awle her life, womans neuer weare preeches in Wales, 'tis not possible, we are awle in treames and visions, very treames and visions.

sp.speaker: Ioc.
sp.p: Sure we are awle awak'd, sir, and it was Selina, did she not say she would obscure her selfe from her Fathers knowledge, and liue among the Shepheards hard by?

sp.speaker: Ien.
sp.p: It may be, but it is very impossible.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: I am amaz'd, when was she seene?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Not to day, sir, I haue searcht her Chamber, and almost turn'd it out ath' window, but no Selina.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: It is very strange, is not your man Gorgon come back?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: What should this meane, it is a strange absence, ath' wedding day too.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: That angers me most, sir.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: My heart misgiues me, some fatall accident vpon my life, is hapned to her.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: Hast thou happy newes?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: I haue traueiled all the Towne o're, and can meete no intelligence of her.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Be dumbe, night-Rauen, she's lost, she's lost,
The Fates sure make conspiracy to take
My Daughters from me: one I lost because
I would not giue her, and I haue repented
Full iustice for it, and am I so vnhappy
To lose Selina too? but Ile not sleepe,
Vntill I finde her either aliue or dead.
Rufaldo, you haue interest in this sorrow,
Ioine in the inquisition. Oh my Girle Selina.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: Haue I beene yong for this? if I finde her not, I will run, I will run, I will run mad, mad.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: No more, I know where her clothes be: if it take, applaud my inuention: I haue coozned my owne Father before now, and I will try new conclusions, but I must haue thy assistance and secresie: if my Sister haue a conceit of mirth to put vpon vs, I may chance put her to proue her selfe Selina, or remoue her with a Habeas corpus.

sp.speaker: Ien.
sp.p:
Iocarelloes, awle is true, Selina is gone in Shepheards vestiments to the woods & Forrests, but her wil make trauels and ambulations after her: neuer was Sentilman ith' hole world loue as Ienkin now, to make iourneyes & peregrinations for a womans, looke you: but if her finde her, as know her very well, her will there make awle sure works and performances, warrant you Pages, here is moneyes,
pray you make prouisions of breads and victuals too, know vds are very bare places, and Shenkin was alwaies haue cud stomacks and appetites, looke you, pray you, doe, pray you, doe.

div.stage: COMPLEMENT-SCHOOLE. Enter Gasparo habited punctually, Master of the Schoole, and Gorgon his Vsher.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: Be the hangings vp, Curculio, and all the Chaires and Stooles put into methode? the day is old, me thinkes, time runs fast, me thinkes, vpon the minute, brings my disciples. Doe my bils of complement still relish, Curculio, doe they please the pallat, ha?

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.p: My most ingenious and noble Criticotaster, brauely bils, pils you should say, not fac'd, but lin'd, with gold they swallow 'em greedily, and still flocke to 'em, and conglomerate my sonne and heire of the Muses: a proclamation is as quiet as the poore mans box, no man lookes after it, not a Balladmonger has any audience: but happy is the man that rides first poast to your papers & cryes admirable: your old men looke vpon 'em with their spectacles, as they would eye an obligation within a minute of forfeyture.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: Thou hast eaten vp the furies already, and speakest all buskins, but close walke in the cloudes, yet I haue not heard of any Mountebanke of wit durst euer attempt to set vp shop ath' trade yet: but whist, Vsher, take your place.

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.p: Foot, 'tis Bubulcus.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: This is the Complement-Schoole.

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.p: Three cuts and a halfe, hey. I giue you, sir, generous salutation, and wish a faire morne descend vpon you: thrice Noble Spirit, welcome, does your worship desire to bee sprinkled with the drops of Hellicon, to gather the Pippins of Pernassus, and haue your forehead fillited with Apollinean Bayes, or Laurell?

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Troth, sir, I doe not know how to conster what you say, although I know it be Latine, sir: the cause of my comming to you, is to let you vnderstand, that here is a Complement-Schoole, and I haue great desire to be taught some of your figaries, and braue words, I doe meane to pay for't soundly too, sir: I thanke my starres, as they say, I haue ready money about me.

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.p: You shall be verberated, and reuerberated, my exact piece of stollidity: please you draw neere, there is the starre of Eloquence, vnder whom I am an Hypodidascall, in English, his Vsher.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: A Gentleman Vsher at least.

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.p: Approach without feare: here is a Pupill, sir, desires to suck the hony of your eloquence, he is a Gentleman in Folio.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: Your accession is gratefull, my most gentile lump of insipience: what complement doth arride the pallate of your generosity?

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: What saies he pray, in English?

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.p: He askes what kind of verbosity you would be practis'd in? because I perceiue you are raw, I will descend to your capacity, he askes what complement you would learne?

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Why looke you, sir, I would haue two kindes of complements: for, sir, I am in loue, and I am in hate.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: How? in loue, and hate too?

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Yes, I am in loue with a Wench, and would haue a delicate speech for her, and I am in hate with a Gentleman, a yong Animall, and I would kill him now without danger of the Law: to tell you true, hee did abuse me in the presence of my sweet-heart, and did (sauing this good company) kisse my backside.

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p:
But it was with his foote, sir: now in regard I haue not the heart to kill him with my sword, I would cut him in pieces, and murder him with mouth-guns: looke
you, sir, here's money, please your selfe: but I pray you giue me a powdring speech, for I would blow him vp: I beseech you, if euer you put gall into your Inke, make it a bitter speech.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: Sir, I will draw you a sublime speech shall coniure him.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Pray doe, for he has a great spirit in him.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: Vsher, in the meane time entertaine him with some copie of amarous complement.

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.p: There is an Vshers fee belongs to my place.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Here's gold for your fee, I receiued it for good fee simple, I am sure.

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.l: Simple, I am sure: so, sir, looke you, I should teach
you to make a leg first, but these postures anon.
Resplendent Mistris, for thy face doth farre
Excell all other, like a blazing Starre
We mortals wonder at, vouchsafe to cast
Out of those sparkling Diamond eyes thou hast,
A sacred Influence on thy vowed creature,
That is confounded with thy forme and feature.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Admirable!

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.p: Goddesse of Cyprus.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Stay, I doe not like that word Cypres, for shee'le thinke I meane to make Hatbands on her, cannot you call her Taffata Goddesse, or if you goe to stuffe, cloth a Gold were richer.

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.p: Oh, there's a conceit, Cyprus is the embleme of morning, and here by Cyprus you declare how much you pine and mourne after her, sir.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Very good, pray you goe on.

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.p: Goddesse of Cyprus, Venus is a slut.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Stay, who doe I call slut now? the Goddesse of Cyprus, Venus, or my Loue?

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.p: You doe tell the Goddesse, that Venus is a slut.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: I doe so.

sp.speaker: Gor.
sp.p: For thou art Venus faire, and she is not.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: How is she Venus faire, when then I call her slut to her face?

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.l: No, sir, your Loue is Venus faire, and shee is not:
That makes plaine the other, that she is a slut.
O that I were a flea vpon thy lip,
There would I sucke for euer, and not skip.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.l: Sucke?

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.l: That is, you would not bite her by the lip.
Or if thou thinkst I there too high am plast,
Ile be content to sucke below thy waste.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.l: Which side she please.

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.l: Thy foote I'de willing kisse, but that I know,
Thou wouldst not haue thy seruant stoope so low.
She will giue you leaue to kisse higher.
Oh speake thou, wilt be mine? and I will be
The truest Worme e're trod on shoo to thee.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Worme?

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.p: By Worme you doe insinuate and wriggle your selfe into your affection, and shee by shoo will conceiue your desire the length of her foote: how doe you like it, sir?

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: I would not for forty pounds but I had come to complement: why, I shall bee able in a small time to put downe a reasonable Gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.p: Oh, any ordinary Lady, you must get it without Booke. Now to make your legs.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: I haue two made to my hands.

sp.speaker: Gor.
sp.p: Oh, by no meanes, your legs are made to your feete.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.l: Beauty and graces dwell vpon the face
Of my disciple Delia.

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.l: Muses inspire you: what, at study?

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.l: Negotiating a little with the Muses.

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.l: See me salute her.
As many happinesses waite on Delia,
As beames shoote from the Sunne this pleasant morne.

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.l: As many thankes requite you, as that Sunne
Is old in minutes since the day begun.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: What's she, Curculio?

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.p: Her Mistresses best moueable, a Chamber-maide.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: She is an early riser: at Schoole so soone?

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.p: She is an early riser, and yet sometime as soone downe as vp, she cannot be quiet for the Seruingmen, 'tis her houre betweene eight a clocke and her Mistris rising, to come to discipline.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: 'Tis a pretty smug Wench, is her name Delia? she has a pretty name too.

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.p: Oh, sir, all her credit is in her good name: it was Diana's the Goddesse of chastity, and therefore when she marries, she may cuckold her Husband by a priuiledge, for Diana gaue hornes to Actaeon.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Where's Master Criticotaster?

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: Who's that?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Sir, my Master has sent you a little gold, he desires you send him the speech he should speake at Sessions in the Country, he's now riding downe.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: Sir Valentine Wantbraine, that has neuer a Clarke?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: The same, Sir.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: Newly put into Commission for the peace, being puisne, it fals to him to giue the charge. I haue drawne it, let me see in Comitatu, &c. here, read it, Curculio, he may the better instruct his Master, a touch, a touch.

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.p:
Good men of the Iury for this Session, I will not implicate you with ambages and circumstances, I am vnwilling to confound your little wits with affected diuisions of my narration, into quis, quid, quomodo, and quandoes: I will neither vtter by grosse, nor part my speech into a doozen of long points, knotted often in the middle, and vntagd in the end; you are to present Malefactors, whereof you are the chiefe— Reformers, and seeing you stand
ready for your charge, I will giue fire to this great piece of seruice, & send you all off with a powder, that in any case we may goe to dinner betimes, &c.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: So, 'tis enough: beare my respects to your Master, tell him 'tis a speech will doe him credit, bid him learne it perfectly without Booke.

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.p: And doe you heare, if he chance to be at a nonplus, he may helpe himselfe with his beard and handkercher, or it will be a good posture for his hand now and then to be fumbling with his bandstrings. Farewell.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: Mistris Medulla, the Sun of honour shine vpon your hopes, till it sublime you to a Ladiship: I will attend you presently.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.p: Sirra, bid your fellow make ready the Caroch, and attend me here about an houre hence, I will ride home.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: What Gentlewoman is that?

sp.speaker: Gor.
sp.p: An old Country Gentlewoman, that hath buried her Husband lately, and comes vp to be a Lady, for she sweares she will not marry any more Gentlemen: she is fallen out with a Iustice of Peaces wife in the Country, and she will haue a Knight, though she pay for his Horse-hier, to spight her neighbours.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: A word with you, sir.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Your friend and Master Bubulcus. Ha you done, sir?

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.l: The Cupidinaean fires burne in my brest,
And like the Ouen Etna, I am full
Of Squibs and Crackers.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: This will powder him.

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.p:
Lady, wounded by your beauty, I will acknowledge mercy if you kill me not, yet rather murther me, then vulnerate still your creature, vnlesse you meane to medicine where you haue hurt, and I implore no better remedy then I may deriue from the instrument wherewith you pierced mee, like Achilles Speare, your eye hauing shot
lightning into my brest, hath power with a smile to fetch out the consuming fire, and yet leaue my heart inflam'd.

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.p: Sir, although where I am not guilty of offence, I might deny iustly, to descend to a satisfaction: yet rather then I would be counted a murtherer, I would study to preserue so sweet a modell as your selfe; and since you desire my eye which enflamed you, should with the vertue of a gracious smile make you happy in your fire, it shall shine as you would haue it, and disclaime that beame shall shine vpon another obiect.

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.l: So, very well, this is your cunning lesson.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.l: Some strangers, Curoutio.

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.l: Sir, the Country comes in vpon vs.

div.stage: Enter an Old-man with his Sonne.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.l: Is not here a Complement-Schoole?

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.l: A Schoole of generous education, sir.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: I haue brought my Sonne to bee a Scholler, I doe meane to make him a Courtier, I haue an offer of fiue or sixe Offices for my money, and I would haue him first taught to speake.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: He is a great childe, cannot he speake yet?

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: In what kinde of complement, please you, venerable Sir, to be edoctrinated? But we will withdraw.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Come, for another lesson, my braue Mars,
Now I am fit to quarrell with the Starres,
And catch at Ioue.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.l: What's hee?

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.l: Orlando Furioso.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: By the blood-staind fauchion of Mauors I will carbonado thee, keep off, or in my fury I will cut thee into Atomes, and blow thee about the world.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.l: I hope he does but complement.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: I will out-labour Ioue-borne Hercules,
And in a greater fury ransack Hell:
Teare from the Sisters their contorted curles,
And wrack the Destinies on Ixions Wheele,
Braine Proserpine with Sisiphs rowling stone,
And in a brazen Caldron choakt with Lead,
Boyle Minos, Eacus, and Radamant,
Throw Pluto headlong into moorish Fennes,
And sooty Regions.
Dam vp Cocitus with tormented soule,
And batter downe the brazen gates of Hell,
Make the Infernall three-chapt Band-dog rore.
Cram Tantalus with Apples, lash the Fiends
With Whips of Snakes, and poysoned Scorpions,
Snatch chain'd Prometheus from the Vultures maw,
And feede him with her liuer, make old Charon
Waft backe againe the soules, or buffet him
With his owne Oares to death.

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.p: So, so, 'tis well, you shall take forth a new lesson, sit downe and breathe.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.l: 'Twas a deuillish good speech.

div.stage: Enter a Iustice of Peaces Clerke, Ingeniolo.

sp.speaker: Ing.
sp.l: Oh, why did nature make thee faire and cruell?

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.l: What spruce fellow's this?

sp.speaker: Gor.
sp.p: He is an hundred & fifty pounds a yard in potentia, a Yeomans sonne, and Iustice of Peaces Clarke, hee is in loue with a Farmers daughter, and thus he speakes his passion in blanke Verse.

sp.speaker: Inge.
sp.l: Thou art some Goddesse, that to amaze the earth
With thy celestiall presence, hath put on
The habit of a mortall, gods sometimes
Would visit Countrey houses, and guild ore
A sublunary habitation
With glory of their presence, and make heauen
Descend into an Hermitage: Sure thy father
Was Maias sonne, disguis'd in Shepheards weeds,
And thou dost come from Ioue, no maruell then
We Swaines doe wonder at thee, and adore,
Venus her selfe the Queene of Cytheron,
When she is riding through the milky way,
Drawne with white Doues, is but a blowze, and must,
When thou appearest, leaue her Bird-drawne Coach,
And giue the reines to thee, and trudge afoot
Along the heauenly plaines, paued with starres,
In duty of thy excellence, while the gods
Looking amaz'd from their cristall windowes,
Wonder what new-come Deity doth call
Them to thy adoration.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.l: O, heauenly Farmers daughter!

sp.speaker: Gor.
sp.l: Ile call him in; Ingeniolo!

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Your seruant, sir. Lady, I kisse your hand, and reuerence the antiquity of your vestment, Delia. Fortune let fall her riches on thy head, that thou maist fill thy apron. I am your humble obseruicer, and wish you all cumulations of prosperity.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Sir, I desire to sucke below yor waste.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: I doe euaculate my selfe to be your shadowes, my generous condisciples.

sp.speaker: Gor.
sp.l: This is Scholler-like.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.l: Hee's one of the head forme, I warrant.

div.stage: Enter Gasparo, the old man and his sonne.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: Sir, I receiue your sonne, and will wind vp his ingeny, feare it not, but first he must be vnder my Vsher, who must teach him the postures of his body, how to make legs and cringes, and then he shall bee aduanced to a higher Classe. Curculio, licke him with your method into some proportion, take off the roughnesse of his behauiour, and then giue him the principles of salutation.

sp.speaker: Old.
sp.p: Law you there, boy, hee will teach you the principles of saltation. Well, good-morrow, sir, Ile leaue my Iewell.

sp.speaker: Gor.
sp.p: Your Iewell may haue the grace to be hang'd one day.

sp.speaker: Ien.
sp.p: Blesse you Sentlemen awle, and your studies and contemplations: is here a Schoole of Complements, pray you?

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: A place of generous breeding.

sp.speaker: Ien.
sp.p: Generous preeding, harke you, her name was Ienkin, a good Sentleman, 'tis knowne, her take no pleasures and delectations in vrds and phrases of Rhetricks; Welsemen haue awle hearts & fidelities, marke you, her was going along pout creat businesse, but casting her eyes & visions vpon your Pils and significations of your skils & professions, looke you, her come in, to see the fashions and manners of your exercises, and yet if your vrships has any Madrigals and Pastorall Canticles, looke you, for in truthes and verities was going now to the Vds and Forrests, and meane to turne Shepheards goddillings, her will giue you good payments of awle your inuentions, and Muses, pray you now.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: Amorous Pastorals? I can furnish you, venerable sir.

lg.l: Turne, Amarilsis, to thy Swane,
Thy Damon cals thee backe againe,
Here is a pretty Arbor by,
Where Apollo cannot pry,
Here let's sit, and while I play
Sing to my Pipe a Roundelay.

sp.p: How like you it, sir?

sp.speaker: Ien.
sp.p: Roundelayes very good, here is moneyes and considerations, looke you.

sp.speaker: Gor.
sp.l: We acknowledge your bounty, my Tenth-worthy.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p:
So Mistris, I haue trespass'd on your patience, now I will take occasion by the fore-locke. You can say your lecture: haue you your hand-kercher ready, that when a Sutor comes, you may put him off with wiping your eyes, as if teares stood in 'em euer since your husband was buried; well, suppose I haue had accesse to your chamber, I begin,
Lady, thinke it not strange, if Loue which is actiue in my bosome, force me to turne petitioner, that I may be reckened amongst your seruants; all my ambition, sweetest, is to be made happy in your affection, which I will study to deserue in my vtmost possibilities.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.p: Alas, alas, I had a husband.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: Very well counterfeited, nay weepe not, those eyes were made to shine, not waste with dew: if it be for the remembrance of him you haue lost, recouer him againe, by placing your good opinion on a man shall sweat to doe you seruices.

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.l: It doth not, sir, become our modesty
To talke of loue so soone, you will renew
My passion for his losse, and draw downe teares
Afresh vpon his Hearse: you doe not well
T' oppresse a widdow thus, I pray, sir, leaue me,
At least I will enioyne you, if you stay,
To speake no more of loue, it is vnwelcome.
What, am I perfect?

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: So 'twas very well, at the next lesson you shall learne to be more cunning.

sp.speaker: Gor.
sp.p: Wilt please you heare the Nouice?

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: Good boy, speake out.

sp.speaker: Offe.
sp.p: God saue you, sir, felicities be accumulated vpon you, sir, I thanke you generous sir, you oblige me to be your seruant, sir, in all my— p— o— s— possibilitie, sir, I honour your remembrance, sir, and shall bee proud to doe you my obseruance, sir, most noble sir.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: Very hopefull now: a repetition all together, the more, the merrier.

sp.speaker: Infor.
sp.p: What, at Barley-breake? which couple are in hell? are not you Hellen, whose insatiate lust ruin'd faire Illium? and you sir Paris with a golden nose? harke you, Rufaldo is married to Selina.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Who? that's my father in Law.

sp.speaker: Infor.
sp.p: How, your father? looke, hee has clouen feete, I am glad I haue found you, what are you in hell for?

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: Insinuate to 'em all for their owne safeties, hee's desperate mad, bid none stirre hence.

sp.speaker: Infor.
sp.l: Hey, how came you all thus damn'd?

sp.speaker: Ien.
sp.l: Damn'd, who's damn'd? is Ienkin damn'd?

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: I beseech you, sir, to maintaine the credit of my Schoole, I shall be vndone else, humour him a little.

sp.speaker: Ien.
sp.p: Will you haue her be damn'd? when heare you pray' a Welshman was damn'd? of all things in the vrld, her cannot abide to be damn'd.

sp.speaker: Gor.
sp.l: See if you can roare him away.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Keepe off, I am Hercules, sonne of Alcmena,
Compress'd by Ioue, Ile carbonado thee.

sp.speaker: Infor.
sp.l: How, art thou Hercules?
Lye there, vsurper of Alcides name,
Bold Centaure: so he's dead, by this I proue
I am Ioue borne.

sp.speaker: Ien.
sp.p: Well, for your credits and reputations, her care not to be damn'd for companies and fellowships, looke you, has hee knock'd him downe? would hee had knock'd Ienkin downe.

sp.speaker: Infor.
sp.p: Now, on with your relations, and tell me all the stories of your fortunes.
sp.l: 'Tis I am Hercules, sent to free you all.
What are you damn'd for? In this Club behold
All your releasements. What are you?

sp.speaker: Gor.
sp.l: Stand in order and be damn'd.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.l: I am the conscience of an Vsurer,
Who haue beene damn'd these two and twenty yeeres,
For lending money gratis.

sp.speaker: Infor.
sp.l: How, a Vsurer? why didst not
Corrupt the Deuill to fetch thy soule away?
Heele take a bribe for lending money gratis.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.l: Yes, sir, for thankes: I tooke no interest,
For at the lending of each hundred pound,
They brought my home some twenty or thirty thanks,
Indeed 'twas paid in gold.

sp.speaker: Infor.
sp.l: Oh golden thankes I well, goe to, Ile release you,
Vpon condition you shall build an Hospitall,
And die a begger. What are you?

sp.speaker: Gor.
sp.l: The soule of a Watchman.

sp.speaker: Infor.
sp.p: How came you damn'd? could not you watch the Deuill?

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.p: He tooke me napping on Midsummer Eue, and I neuer dream 't on him.

sp.speaker: Infor.
sp.p: Your wife had giuen you Opium ouer night.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: No sir, I had watch'd three nights before, and because I would not winke at two or three drunkards as they went reeling home at twelue a clocke at night, the Deuill owed me a spight.

sp.speaker: Infor.
sp.p: Well, you shall bee prentice to an Alcumist, and watch his Stills night, by night, not sleepe till he get the Philosophers-stone. What are you?

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.p: Sir, I am a Chamber-maid.

sp.speaker: Infor.
sp.p: What are you damn'd for?

sp.speaker: Del.
sp.p: Not for reuealing my Mistris secrets, for I kept them better then mine owne, but keeping my maiden-head till it was stale, I am condemn'd to lead Apes in hell.

sp.speaker: Infor.
sp.p: Alas, poore wench, vpon condition you will bee wise hereafter, and not refuse Gentlemens proffers, learne pride euery day, and painting, bestow a courtesie now and then vpon the Apparitor to keepe counsell, I release you, take your Apes, and Monkies away with you, and bestow them on Gentlewomen, and Ladies, that want plai-fellowes. What are you?

sp.speaker: Cle.
sp.p: I am an Vndersheriffe, sir, damn'd because I told the debtors, writs were out against 'em, brought 'em to composition without arrests, fauoured poore men for a whole yeere together, was very good in my Office, gaue vp a iust account at the yeeres end, and broke.

sp.speaker: Infor.
sp.p: Oh, miracle! an honest man! thou shalt bee Church-warden to a Parish, draw the presentments, and keepe the poore mens box for seuen yeares together, 'tis pitty, but thou the eldest haue fifty writer, to propagate honest generation. What are you?

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.p: A Iustices wife ith' the Countrie, sir.

sp.speaker: Infor.
sp.p: And who drew yourmittimus hither? what are you damn'd for?

sp.speaker: Med.
sp.p: For refusing Sattin gownes, and veluet petticots, turning backe Capons at Christinas, and Sessions times, and making much of one of my husbands seruants, meerely for his honestie and good seruice towards me.

sp.speaker: Infor.
sp.p: 'Tis iniustice, you shall burie your husband quickly, weare some blackes a while for fashion sake, & within a moneth be married to his Clarke, vnlesse you will be diuided among the Seruing-men. What are you?

sp.speaker: Old mans son.
sp.p: A younger brother, sir, borne at the latter end of the weeke, and waine of the Moone, put into the world to seeke my owne fortune, got a great estate of wealth by gaming and wenching, and so purchas'd vnhappily this state of damnation you see me in.

sp.speaker: Infor.
sp.p: Came you in't by purchase? then you doe not claime it by yours fathers interest as an heire: well, I will ease you of the estate, because it is litigious, and you shall make presently a bargaine and sale of it to a Scriuener, that shall buy it of you, and pay you both his eares downe vpon the naile for it. What are you?

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: I am a Horse-courser.

sp.speaker: Infor.
sp.p: And couldst not thou out-ride the Deuill?

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p:
I had not the grace to mend my pace, I was an honest Horse-courser, and suffered euerie foole to ride me, I knew not what belonged to horse-play, let the world kicke at me, I neuer winch'd, all that I am damnd for, is, that desiring to thriue in the world, and to haue good-lucke to horse-flesh, I ambled to the bed of a Parsons wife that was coltish once, and gaue her husband a Horse for't in
good fashion, he nener gaue me godamercie for't, indeed it prou'd afterwards to haue the Yellowes.

sp.speaker: Infor.
sp.p: There was some colour for't: well, since your occupation is foundred, you shall trot euery day afoot, and walke a knaue in the Horse-faire. What are you?

sp.speaker: Ien.
sp.p: Her haue no minde at all to bee damn'd, becar her will fight with her & kill awle the Deuils in hell: diggon.

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.p: Sfoot, heres more adoe to get one Welshman damn'd, then a whole Nation. Sir, 'tis but in iest.

sp.speaker: Ien.
sp.p: In iests, is it in iests? well, looke you, her will bee contented to be damn'd in iests and merriments for you.

sp.speaker: Infor.
sp.p: You will tell me what you are damn'd for?

sp.speaker: Ien.
sp.p: And her be so hot, was get some bodyes else to be damn'd for Ienkin, her will tell her in patiences, looke you, her was damn'd for her valour, and ridding the vrld of Monsters, looke you, Dragons with seuen heads, and Serpents with tailes a mile long, pray you.

sp.speaker: Infor.
sp.p: Oh, let me embrace thee, worthy in my armes, Ile charme the Destinies for their bold attempt, for cutting off thy threed, thou shalt cut their throats, and be instald Lord in Elisium, Oh, let me hug thee, Owen Glandower.

sp.speaker: Ien.
sp.p: Owen Glandower was her cousin, pray you.

sp.speaker: Infor.
sp.p: Goe your waies all: stay, take hence Prometheus and burie him, if you come into hell againe, there's no releasement.

sp.speaker: Ien.
sp.p: So, farewell Sentlemen, now her meane to make trauels and peregrinations, to the vds and plaines, looke you, very fast. Good speed to awle.

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.p: We thanke thee Iouiall Hercules.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: Liue long thou King of hell. So, so, well done of all sides, here our Schoole breakes vp, I might haue runne mad like, had I not taken off the edge of melancholy. Thus poore Gentleman. O Loue thou art a madnesse, Drawing our soules with ioy, to kill with sadnesse.

sp.speaker: Infor.
sp.p: So, so, poore soules, how glad they are of liberty. This is a hot house, I doe scorch and broyle: Ile seeke the Elisian fields out, and dye there.

div.head: Actus quartus, Scena prima.
div.stage: Enter Antonio drest in Selinaes apparell, with Hillaria.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Haue I not done my part, wench, with confidence to proceed thus farre with thy father? either I am infinitly like my sister, or they are all mad with credulitie: but our good fathers are blinded with their passions, and that helps me much: well, I doe but thinke vpon the nights worke, there lyes my master-piece, I haue it, 'tis for thy sake Hillaria, I haue assum'd this habit, the end will speake it.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: But what will you doe? Antonio is lost now.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Well enough, is suppos'd to goe after Selina, and is not return'd yet, out of my brotherly loue, they will imagine I haue but taken a iourney in quest of a sister, time enough to returne agen, and hee goes farre, that neuer does wench by Story. Enter Bubulcus whetting his sword .Heres Bubulcus.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Antonio is gone, no newes of him: I am glad of that, I hope he will come no more.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: How now? what meanes this? what! sword drawne?

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: And he is whetting it.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: For heauens sake, whats the matter?

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Nay, nothing, nothing, I doe but— a—

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: By my virginity you make me afraid, whats the matter?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: He meanes to fight with some body on my life.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Heauen defend it, good sir, tell me.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Bee not afraid, Gentlewomen, for I doe but, you see.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: But what?

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Whet my long knife, somebody shall smart for't, but—

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: He does meane to challenge somebody.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: I charge you, if you loue, tell me who's your enemy.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.l: Nay, no body, I doe not meane to fight, if I liue.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: What?

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Nay, nothing, sweet Ladies, be not troubled, I doe but sharpen my sword.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.l: Tell me the truth, why?

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: I was eating Oysters tother day, and I had neuer a knife, and so—

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Come, come, there is some other matter in't, pray tell me.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Welll, you are my friends, if you chance to heare of any mans death shortly, then say Bubulens.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: I hope you doe not meane to kill any man i'th field, you doe make me tremble, Ile assure you.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.l: No, no, sweet-heart, doe not tremble, I will but—
Lose my honour? Ile be caru'd first.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: What a Capon's this? pray let me perswade you.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.l: And me.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.l: No, no, 'tis but in vaine to perswade me, I'm resolu'd, if you loue me, doe not vse any arguments:
The Cupidinaean fires burne in my brest,
And like the Ouen Etna I am full
Of squibs and crackers. I had almost forgot—

sp.speaker: Hil.
