sp.p: The Ouen Etna Ile bee baked then: what a fury are you in? he lookes like the god of Warre.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: The god of Warre? I thinke I haue reason. Hillaria, I must, and I will, and all the world shall not hold me.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.l: But you shall not goe away thus, till you be calmer.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.l: O that I were a flea vpon his lip,
There would I sucke for euer, and not skip.
I will carbonado him, his face doth farre
Excell all other like a blazing starre
We mortals wonder at. Vouchsafe to cast
Off the sparkling diamond eyes thou hast:
O let me goe on, me thy vowed creature,
That is confounded with thy forme and feature.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Is the foole mad?

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: He has something in his head, and it were out: but here comes our Fathers.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Antonio not heard of yet?

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: This morning we wanted a Bride too, but she was found, mary I cryed for her first. Father, come, my Brother Antonio is but gone to looke his Sister: ha, my sweet Wench, when shal's to bed.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: I hope 'tis so, and yet he staies too long. Here's Gorgon: Sirra, where haue you beene all this day?

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.p: Indeed, sir, I haue made inquisition, both my tongue and my feete haue walked, but my Mistris is not to be found or heard of, Ile assure you.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.l: Gorgon, hast lost thy sences? here's Selina.

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.l: Mistris, then we are all made.— He capers.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: But sirra, your Master Antonio's gon.

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.l: Gon in wine, sir, for ioy of his sisters finding agen.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Goe your waies, sirra, and either bring me newes of him, or looke mee in the face no more, you'l finde we iest not.

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.p: Pray', sir, let me take my iourney in the morning, the wedding night is fatall: I hope your worship does but iest, I may be drunke too night, and wake early enough to be gon afore day too, I beseech you sir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Pray', sir, let him stay to night.

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.p: By this hand there he is, where? did not I heare his voice?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Away sirra.

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.p: I haue beene mad all this while, and now am like to be my owne man againe: since there is no remedy, Gentiles all, good night. Gorgon begins to be a wandring Knight.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: I cannot be heartily merry: well, let's leaue these two without any more ceremonies, 'tis late, all ioyes be multiplyed on my Sonne and Daughter: good night, I doe comfort my selfe with hope of Antonio's returne, and yet feares are great.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: Lights there: so, so, welcome thou much expected night, I doe salute thy blacke browes: come, my Selina, shalt finde I haue yong blood: Hillaria, doe seruice to your Mother, make her vnready.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: 'Tis time enough.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: And why should we lose any? I pray thee let her come. I know 'tis your Virgin modesty, loth to part with a Maidenhead, but it must off: come, prethee be not idle: why, thou knowest I married thee, Selina, as thou louest me—

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Sir, by that loue I must entreat you one thing.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.l: Any thing, sweet-heart.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: To ratifie an ancient vow I made.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.l: Any vowes, what is't?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I vowed when euer I married, my husband should not lie with me the first night.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.l: Should any body else?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Not any man.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: Come, 'twas a foolish vow, and must bee broke. Not lie with me the first night? 'twere a sinne beyond incontinency. I had rather lose halfe my estate, then misse thee but an houre out of mine armes this night.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: 'Tis but one night.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: Oh, 'tis an age, a world of time to me: why I haue fed of Oister-pyes, and rumps of Sparrows a whole moneth, in expectation of the first night, and leaue it for a vow?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Indeed you must.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: How? must, come? I know you doe but iest, this is but your deuice to whet me on, and heighten me, as if old age at once hath soakt vp all my marrow. Harke you, how old doe yee thinke I am?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Some threescore and seuenteene.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: Out vpon thy iudgement: why I am not aboue, by all computation, sixe or seuen and thirty: I am restord, renewd, when first I lou'd thee, by this hand I was.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I see then you would tire me, by this beard you must not lie with me to night.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: How? nay then I see you'l try my strength: thus I could force you. Antonio throwes him downe .She has throwne me downe, I know not how to take it, nor well how to beare it, my bones ake, a pox a Gasparo, a my conscience I am an old foole: ha? I will see more, and set a good face on't, you know who I am?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Yes, old Rufaldo.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: Ha, old? 'tis so, my spirits faint agen: what did you marry for?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: To make an asse of you.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Thou credulous foole,
Didst thou imagine I should euer loue thee,
Or lie with thee? but when I haue a child
Would shame the Father: Oh the power of dotage,
That like an inundation doth o'recome
The little world of man, drowne all his reason,
And leaue him spoild, euen of his common sence.
Didst thinke I was a piece of stone sawne out
By Caruers art, so cold, so out of soule,
So empty of all fire to warme my blood,
I'de lie with thee, worse then the frigid Zone,
Or Isicles that hang on beard of winter?
Haue I with wearied patience lookt to see,
When thou'dst lay violent hands vpon thy selfe;
For being so mad, so impudent to loue me,
And wouldst thou bed me too? didst thou not tremble
To dare the holy Rites and nuptiall Tapers?
Oh impious sacriledge! hence, goe waste
Thy selfe with sorrow, pine that halfe-staru'd body,
Vntill thy bones breake thy skinne, and fall
To dust before thy face: nay, you shall endure me:
For since y'aue tyed me to you, I will be
Thy constant Fury, worse then Hags or Night-mare,
If thou dost talke of Loue, or seeke to be
At reconcilement.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.l: Selina, sweet Selina, heare me.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Sweet? oh villanous presumption!

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.l: What will you doe?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Saue a disease, a labour, make an end of you, come sirra, sweare to obserue what I shall impose vpon you.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.l: Oh, any thing, bitter Selina.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: First, you shall neuer sollicite me to lye with you.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.l: Neuer by this hand, and thanke you too.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Stand bare in my presence.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.l: Starke-naked.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Runne of my arrands.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.l: To the worlds end.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: And keep a whore vnder my nose, nay, I will allow it.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.l: If you will haue it so, I am content.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Sweare, sirra.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.l: Flesh, and blood, I doe sweare.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: So, rise. In hope of your conformity, I forbeare to let the punishment be equall with your deserts.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: Oh, I haue married a Deuill, I shall be vtterly disgraced, if this bee knowne: Pray sweet wife, let me begge one request of you, that you would not discredit mee, I will be content to endure your pleasure, doe not forsake my house, I beseech you that you would lye with my daughter.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Shall you appoint my lodging?

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: Oh no, I doe but humbly intreate you will be pleased to lie with my daughter.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Well, since you submit so respectiuely, I will tender your credit in that point vpon your good behauiour, are you not well?

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: I am the worse for you by forty markes. One thing more, vertuous wife, that you would not tell your father, nor any body else, how you haue beaten me: Goodnight, sweet vertuous wife.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Ha, ha, Hillaria, my way to thee is free, I haue beat my passage, and I come to thee.

div.stage: Enter Felice like a Shepheardesse, Selina, Shepheards.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: I had thought the woods and such wilde groues as these,
Had beene the house of rapine, and could not
Afford humanity, beasts, and men like them,
Are wont to make such places desolate:
Did Nature make you thus at first, and are
We that haue Cities, house, and Ciuill Lawes
More rude then you? or hath all vertue chose
You as diuine earth to dwell vpon?
Shepheardesse, indeed I am in loue
With your wild Kingdome here, and would not be
A King abroad, if I might be a subiect
With such faire Nymphes as you.

sp.speaker: 1. Shep.
sp.l: Oh sonne, you would say so,
When our pleasures all you know:
We are not opprest with care,
With which you in Cities are,
A Shepheard is a King, whose Throne
Is a mossie Mountaine, on
Whose top we sit, our crooke in hand,
Like a Scepter of command,
Our subiects, sheepe grazing below,
Wanton frisking to and fro.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.l: We nothing feare, awake nor sleepe,
But the Woolfe goddild our sheepe,
On a Countrey Quill each playes
Madrigals, and pretty Layes
Of passions, and the force of Loue,
And with Ditties heauen moue.
Birds will listen to our song,
And to leauy Arbours throng,
To learne our notes, and Mistris name,
Vallies ecchoing with the same.

sp.speaker: 2. Shep.
sp.l: When we hunt, as there is store
Of Deere, the trembling Hare, and Bore,
You would thinke that you had seene
Gods in Shepheards weeds agen.
A hundred pretty Nymphes apace
Tripping ore the lands, and chase,
As many Lads, the gentle aire
Playing with their dangling haire.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.l: Sometimes we dance a Feary round,
Hand in hand vpon the ground,
Shepheards piping, Garlands crowning,
With our harmelesse bosomes drowning.

sp.speaker: 1. Shep.
sp.l: Walke vnto the siluer brooke,
You shall need no other hooke,
To catch the dancing fish withall,
But a song, or Madrigall.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.l: When the clouds let fall their showres,
We haue at hand a hundred bowres,
Where vnder Sweet-bryer, safe are wee
And honey-dropping Woodbind tree,
Here in spight of stormes we tell
Stories of loue, of Philomell,
Of Paris, and the Golden ball,
Of Eccho, and Narcissus fall.

sp.speaker: 3. Shep.
sp.l: Here no false-loue brings despaire,
Iealousie, or suspition, care,
Alwaies happy most of all
On Siluanus festiuall.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: No more, good Shepheards, you vndoe a boy
With the opinion of his happinesse:
If a few Iewels I haue brought with me,
May find acceptance here, I shall bestow them
As freely as your loues haue falne on me.
Nay then, Ile force 'em on you, I haue left
To purchase a Flock with you.

sp.speaker: 1. Shep.
sp.l: We thanke you, gentle boy, gooden,
We must to our Flockes agen.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: But Shepheardesse, or sister if thou wilt,
Oh would thou wert, I preethee call me brother,
Hath Loue a part among you, tell me pray,
What punishment inflict you on false loue?
But sure you are exempt from such
A misery: what then
Is her reward, that out of peeuishnesse
Contemnes the honest passion of her Louer,
Insults vpon his vertue, and doth place
Vnworthily her affection?

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.l: Though such a woman need no curse,
Being one her selfe, or worse,
Yet we Shepheards vse to say,
May she loue another day,
And not be lou'd, dye in despaire,
And haue no other Tombe but aire.

sp.speaker: Infor.
sp.l: A prey, a prey!
Where did you get that face?
That goddesse face? it was Selina's once:
How came you by it? did she on her death-bed
Bequeath her beauty as a legacy,
Not willing it should die, but liue and be
A lasting death to Infortunio?
Oh she was cruell, not to bury it with her!
But I am a foole, 'tis Venus and her Sonne,
Where be your Bow and Arrowes, little Cupid?
Didst thou maliciously spend all thy Quiuer
Vpon my heart, and not reserue one shaft
To make Selina loue me? Tell me, Venus,
Why did you vse me so? you shall no more
Be Queene of Loue. Stay, stay, Cupid was blind,
How comes he now to see? yes, he did see,
He neuer could haue wounded me so right else.
Why then let Fortune haue her eyes agen,
And all things see how wretched I am made.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Oh, is there not within the power of Art,
How to restore this Gentleman?

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.l: There is, and out of that experience we
Haue in these woods, of simples, I doubt not,
But to apply a remedy.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: He will be worthy of your care herein,
And should he be, which I cannot imagine,
Ingratefull to your skill, I would reward it,
And call you mother, or my sister for it.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.l: It seemes you haue some relation to him.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Indeed he is the dearest friend I had:
And if my blood were powerfull to restore him,
Ide spend it like a prodigall. I know Selina.

sp.speaker: Inf.
sp.l: Ha, doe you know Selina? she's married to Rufaldo,
the old Vsurer, that went to bed afore to his money, and begate forty ith' hundred: now he beds Selina,
And layes his rude hand o're her sacred brest,
Embraceth her faire body, now he dares
Kisse her, and suck Ambrosia from her lip.
Those eyes that grace the day, now shine on him,
He her Endimion, she his siluer Moone,
The tongue that's able to rock Heauen asleepe,
And make the musicke of the Spheres stand still,
To listen to the happier aires it makes,
And mend their tunes by it: that voice is now
Deuoted to his eares, those cheekes, those hands,
Would make gods proud to touch, are by his touch
Profaned euery houre: oh, this makes me mad,
But I will fit 'em for it, for Ile die,
It may be then she'le weepe, and let fall teares
Vpon my graue-stone, which shall be of marble,
And hard like her, that if she powre out floods,
No drops shall sinke thorow it to soften me,
I will be wrapt in Lead to keepe out praiers,
For then I know, shee'le beg I would be friends:
But then I will be iust, and hate her loue,
As she did mine, and laugh to see her grieue.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Come, I will fetch Selina to you, if you will sleepe.

sp.speaker: Inf.
sp.l: Will you then? I will liue, & you shall be my best boy.
Come, I scorne to weepe, or shead another teare:
Sit downe, Ile haue a Garland for my Boy,
Of Phoenix feathers: Flowers are too meane
To sit vpon thy temples; in thy face
Are many Gardens, Spring had neuer such:
The Roses and the Lillies of thy cheekes
Are slips of Paradise, not to be gathered,
But wondred at.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: But you said you would sleepe: when slept you last?

sp.speaker: Inf.
sp.l: I remember, before I lou'd, but that I know not when
I slept soundly, and dreamt of gathering Nosegayes.
'Tis vnlucky to dreame of hearbs and flowers.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: For Selina's sake Ile try my best skill on him, Get him to sleepe, your presence I see is powerfull, yonder's a pleasant Arbour, procure him thither while I prepare the hearbs, whose precious iuyce may with Heauens blessing make him well againe.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: A thousand blessings on you. Come, sir, goe with me, and when you haue slept, Ile fetch Salina to you.

sp.speaker: Iuf.
sp.p: Prethee doe, I am very drowzy: come, Ile dreame of some thing, my eyes are going to bed, and leaden sleepe doth draw the curtaines o're them.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Will you goe with me?

sp.speaker: Inf.
sp.l: Yes, and we will picke a dish of Strawberies.

div.stage: Enter Ienkin, hauing lost his way.

sp.speaker: Ien.
sp.p: Has almost lost her selfe in these woods and wildernesses, was very weary of these iourneyes and trauels in foote-backs: haue not since her commings beheld any reasonable creatures: blesse vs awle, Iocarello is lost too, cannot tell where, in these mazes and labyrinths. Iocarello, so ho.

sp.speaker: Eccho.
sp.p: So ho.

sp.speaker: Ien.
sp.p: Ha, there's some bodies yet, harke you tere, here is a sentilman of Wales, looke you, desires very much to haue speeches and confabulations with you: where is her?

sp.speaker: Eccho.
sp.p: Here is her.

sp.speaker: Ien.
sp.p: Here is her? knaw not which waies to come to her: pray you tell Ienkin where you be?

sp.speaker: Eccho.
sp.p: Boobie.

sp.speaker: Ien.
sp.p: Poobies? was her call her poobies? 'tis very saucy trauels, her will teach her better manners and moralities, if her get her in reaches and circumferences of her Walsh blades truely.

sp.speaker: Eccho.
sp.p: You lie.

sp.speaker: Ien.
sp.p: How, lies and poobies too? harke you, Ienkin was giue you mawles and knocks, for your poobies, and lies, and indignities, looke for your pates now. Exit with his sword drawne. Enter againe .Here is no bodies but bushes and bryers, looke you, awle is very quiet: so ho, ho.

sp.speaker: Eccho.
sp.p: So ho, ho.

sp.speaker: Ien.
sp.p: Her am very much deceiu'd, now it comes into our mindes if these voyces be not Ecchoes, Eccho.

sp.speaker: Ecc.
sp.p: Eccho.

sp.speaker: Ien.
sp.p: 'Tis very true, but her maruell much, haue her Ecchoes in these Countries pray you?

sp.speaker: Ecc.
sp.p: Yes pray you.

sp.speaker: Ien.
sp.p: Warrant her 'tis a Welsh Eccho, was follow Ienkin in loues out of Wales.

sp.speaker: Ecc.
sp.p: Out of Wales.

sp.speaker: Ien.
sp.p: 'Tis very true, blesse vs awle now, her call to remembrances and memories, her had communications and talkings with this very Ecchoes in Clamorgan-shire, in de vallies and Talles there looke you, her am very glad her hath met with Ecchoes, was borne in her owne Countries, harke you, Ienkin was trauell hither out of loues and affections to Selina.

sp.speaker: Ecc.
sp.p: Nay.

sp.speaker: Ien.
sp.p: Nay, yes very true, pray you tell her, be Selina in these woods, or no?

sp.speaker: Ecc.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Ien.
sp.p: No, where is her den, haue her taken awle these labours and ambulations in vanities? say you, shall Ienkin then goe backe as he came?

sp.speaker: Ecc.
sp.p: Asse he came.

sp.speaker: Ien.
sp.p: Gone? it is not possible, hit may bee Selina was turne spirits and be inuisible rather, she is not gone verily.

sp.speaker: Ecc.
sp.p: There you lye.

sp.speaker: Ien.
sp.p: Lye, very well, you haue priuiledges to giue lyes and awle things in the world, but her will not leaue these woods for awle dat, her will bee Pilgrims all tayes of her lifes, ere her goe without her.

sp.speaker: Ecc.
sp.p: Goe without her.

sp.speaker: Ien.
sp.p: How, not loue Ienkin? then there is a Deuill in awle female sexes: know very well she promise loues and good wills in times, great while agoe, pray you now, her will talke no longer with you. Fare you well Eccho, pray if you meete her Pages, bid her make hasts and expeditions after her. Fare you well.

sp.speaker: Ecc.
sp.p: Fare you well.

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.p:
I thinke Iupiter has snatch'd vp my Master Antonio,
to make a Ganimede on him, hee is not to be found yet, I haue search 't all the Tauernes ith Towne, I am sure, and that method my nose led me to, hoping he had beene a good fellow, but, non est iuuentus, well, my stocke is spent, but with this terrible face a buffe Ierkin, and a roaring basket-hilt, Gorgon will haue a tricke of wit to beare his owne charges: but here comes a Gentleman, to my postures now.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: I am resolu'd.

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.p: Good your worship bestow a small piece of siluer vpon a poore Souldier, new-come out of the Low-Countries, that haue beene in many hot seruices, against the Spaniard, the French, and great Turke. I haue beene shot seuen times thorow the body, my eyes blowne vp with gun-powder, halfe my skull seard off with a Canon, and had my throat cut twice in the open field: good your worship take compassion vpon the caterwaking fortunes of a forlorne Gentleman, that haue lost the vse of my veines: good your generous nature take compassion vpon me, I haue but foure fingers and a thumbe vpon one hand: can worke, and woonnot: one small piece of gratefull siluer, to for my lodging, I beseech you venerable sir.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: Canst not see?

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.p: Onely a little glimmering, sir, the beames of your gentility haue radiated, and infused light into my poore lanternes, sir.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: Can you feele then?

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.p: Oh, sir, that faculty alone, fortune and nature haue left inuiolated.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.l: Heres somewhat for thee.
What, can you see now?

div.stage: He kickes him, and Gorgon opens his eyes.

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.l: Gasparo, is it you? Pox on your beneuolence.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.l: Whence came this proiect of wit?

sp.speaker: Gor.
sp.p:
From the old predicament. Faith, necessity that has no
Law, put me into this habit: my Master is turn'd coward, and ran away from me.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: And thou art turn'd Souldier, to fight with him when you meet agen: then thou wantest a Master? harke sirra, what saiest thou to another proiect?

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.p: Oh, I could caper for't.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: I am now leauing the world, and going into the Countrie, woot turne Gipsie, or Shepheard? I am for the woods, canst Madrigals yet?

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.l: Phillis faire, doe not disdaeine
The loue of Coridon thy Swaine.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: Excellent I weele turne Shepheards presently, thou shalt be Phillis, and Ile be Coridon: let me alone to prouide Russets, Crooke, and Tarbox: they say there's good hospitality in the Woods, and Songs and pastimes vpon Siluaum day.

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.p: But that were pretty, shall I be a woman?

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: By any meanes, thou hast a good face already, a little simpering will doe it, Ile accomodate thee early, keep thy owne counsell, and Ile warrant thee for a Maide-marrian.

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.p: Foote! shall I runne into my coates agen? goe to, put me into what shape you will, Ile play my part: mee thinkes I doe feele an hundred rurall animals taking vp my petticoate already.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Pray' forward with your relation.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: As I was saying, hauing challenged Antonio for the affront he did me before Hillaria, here by heauen, you must say nothing.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Not a syllable.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Hee did accept the challenge, and the weapons were soone agreed vpon, and wee met: but not a word of fighting, if you loue me.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: You are not come to fighting yet your selfe, but by the way, what were your weapons?

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: A long sword.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Twas long ere you could remember it, me thinkes.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Soone as we came into the place appointed, wee looked about, and saw all cleere.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: As cleere as day on your side.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: We drew, but not a word of fighting, by this hand.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Not by that hand.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: We threw our doublets off, to shew wee had no Coate of maile, or priuie shirt vpon vs, against the lawes of duelling, in fine, I bid him say his prayers.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Twas well thought vpon, and what did you?

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: I let 'em alone, for I knew I should kill him, and haue time enough to say 'em afterwards at my leasure.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: When he had prayed, what then?

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: When he had said his praiers, he thought vpon it, and let fall words tending to reconcilement: a my conscience, he would haue asked me forgiuenesse, but I stood vpon my honour, and would fight with him, and so wee stood vpon our guard: but not a word of fighting, if you loue me.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Oh, by no meanes, but when did you fight?

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Ile tell you, Antonio when he saw no remedie, but that I would needs fight with him, and so consequently kill him, made a desperate blow at my head, which I warded with my dagger, better then he looked for, and in returne, I cut off his left hand, whereat amazed and fainting, I nimbly seconded it, as you know I am very nimble, and run my Rapier into his right thigh, two yards.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Then you were on both sides of him?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Your Rapier, did you not say your weapons were long swords?

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p:
But mine was both a sword and Rapier, there's it, but not a word of fighting, as you loue me: well, not to weary you with the narration of the inumerable wounds I gaue him, I cut off euery ioint from his toe vpwards, to his middle, by these hilts, now you may beleeue me, there
ended Antonio my riuall, iudge, iudge now, whether Bubulcus be valiant or not, but not a word of fighting, as you loue me, let it dye.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Twas very valiantly done.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Harke you, Sweet-heart, doe you not remember who this is, that you haue discouered this businesse too? this is Selina, his owne sister.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: What a rogue was I, not to remember that?

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Doe not you know that she is my mother in Law? nay, nay, plucke vp a good heart, what will you doe? theres no running away.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Haue you neuer an emptie chest?

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: What, to hide your selfe? that I know you would not doe for your credit: draw your sword, and stand vpon your guard, we know you are valiant, that could kill Antonio so brauely.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Hillaria, if euer you lou'd me, oh, I haue made a faire piece of worke, would you not tell me it was his sister? oh, here they come.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: He hath confest it, sir, your Daughter heard it, sir, I charge you lay hands vpon that murtherer, he hath slaine my Brother Antonio.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: Did you heare him confesse it?

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Here's right, confesse and be hang'd now.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: I must confesse I did.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: Bubulcus kill Antonio?

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: By this hand I doe not know how to deny it for my credit.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: Nay then lay hands on him.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Yes Father, Rufaldo, Selina, oh, a plague of all coxcombes, what a rogue was I?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I will haue Iustice, away with him.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: I am a lying rascall by this hand.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: We must require Antonio from you, sir, or your blood answer his. Away with him, Hillaria.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Ile bee hang'd then, Father. Hillaria, will you see me hang'd?

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: There is no remedy: would thou hadst kild his Sister; I am plagued with her, and dare not speake it for shame, Ile doe what I can to get a Repriefe for you; nay, and you kill folkes, you must eene take your fortune.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: A curse of all ill fortune, I kild no body.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Away, I say, out villaine, hence, for I
Doe heare my brothers blood for iustice cry.

div.head: Actus quintus, Scena prima.

sp.speaker: Infor.
sp.l: I doe not know this place, nor who you are,
Nor know I yet my selfe.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.l: Infortunio?

sp.speaker: Infor.
sp.l: That name I once did answer to, but then
I was not banisht to a wildernesse,
Nor slept on such a bed. Oh, if I be
Hee, whom you call Infortunio.
Tell me how I came hither, dost thou weepe?
I prethee tell me, boy, why doe those teares
Drowne thy faire cheekes? but that they will not shew
Manly in me, I'de force my eyes to weepe too,
And we would sit vpon a banke, and play
Drop-teare, till one were bankrout. You amaze me:
I aske how I came hither? answer me
With other language, if you doe not meane
I came by water, which you might expresse too
In words as well, nay, better, for you now
Are cruel to your selues, and murder me:
Tell me, or I shall be mad.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Oh, stay: that brought Infortunio hither,
You haue now told your selfe, distraction brought you.

sp.speaker: Infor.
sp.l: Ha distraction? now you increase my wonder:
Was I mad, or doe not you by answering,
Study to make me so? why should I be mad,
Or being so, how came I well againe?
For if I dreame not, I am well and calme.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: You owe this Shepheardesse for your restore,
Whose skill heauen made so happy.

sp.speaker: Infor.
sp.l: Did you, faire Shepheardesse restore me then,
And by your art recouer natures losse?
All my wel-beings your's: but yet if you
Could so Physicion-like cure the disease
Which is but the effect of some distemper,
You then should know the cause: for else you are
Vncertaine in your applications.
Pray tell me then, why was I mad?

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: This Lad can tell you that, better then I,
But if his sorrow will not let his tongue
Deliuer it, Ile tell you sir; you were in loue.

sp.speaker: Infor.
sp.p: With whom, I pray?

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: One whom they call Selina.

sp.speaker: Infor.
sp.l: Ha, Selina? in what a depth of black forgetfulnesse
Is Infortunio fallen into? Selina,
Could I forget Selina? oh Shepheardesse,
I was not mad till now: for can I be
My selfe, and forget her? oh, in this question
I am vndone: for I doe hold my selfe
And all my vnderstanding by her name,
I am a begger, she hath purchas'd all,
Nor am I master of one thought of comfort
I borrow not from her: what curse was falne
Vpon my memorie, to forget Selina?

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Sir, you remember her too well, vnlesse
She would deserue it better.

sp.speaker: Infor.
sp.l: It is not in her power to deserue, boy,
For she is now beholding for her selfe
Vnto another. Oh, this teares my soule,
You did not well to release me of my furies,
And make me sensible againe of that
Was my first corrosiue, it was vnfriendly:
Oh, twas a happinesse to be mad, starke mad,
For she being lost, what haue I else to lose?
I was all hers, I gaue my selfe away:
And deedes of gift should hold.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: Why should you be so passionate? let once reason so late recouered, teach you loue your selfe, reseru'd for nobler fortune.

sp.speaker: Infor.
sp.l: It is true, I am a very foole in doing so,
And will you be a Mistris then, and teach me
How to forget my selfe? what saist boy?
Shall I be Shepheard too? I will liue here
And haue thy company, thou art like my Loue,
Shall we Shepheardesse?

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: With all my heart.

sp.speaker: Infor.
sp.l: Come let's sit downe awhile, nature hath spred
Her Carpets for vs here, this is the lowest,
And yet 'tis higher then a Palace: pray
Teach me your Shepheards life, now I doe long
To be a wood-man too, and you shall doe
A double cure vpon me.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: Stay, yonder are some Shepheards, lets on this banke sit downe and prattle. And how long ist, since your Sweet-heart forsooke you?

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.p: It will be a quarter of a yeere next grasse.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: Alas, poore Mopsa, but come, put him out of thy minde, sing him away.

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.p: Laugh, and sing him to his graue shall I?

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: And neuer loue him more.

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.p: Oh no, his loue like a canker hath eate such a great hole into my heart, I cannot forget him, but Ile sing a song of him.

div.stage: Gorgon sings a song, all this while

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: Prethee doe.

sp.speaker: Infor.
sp.l: Here's innocence of all sides, who would liue
Out of this Common-wealth, where honest Swaines
Are Lords and subiects? Here is no acquaintance
With craft and falshood, all their soules are clad
In true simplicity: I will take a truce
With care a while, to talke with this poore wench.
Mopsa I heard you nam'd, pray tell me,
Were you in loue?

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.p: Yes forsooth.

sp.speaker: Infor.
sp.p: With whom, forsooth?

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.p: With a Gentleman that has prou'd vnkind, forsooth, broken his vowes, and oathes, forsooth, hee made much of me, time was, before his father dyed, forsooth, who was a good Yeoman, then he kist me, forsooth, and coll'd surreuerence, but now hee scornes Mopsa: I was his equall once, and haue danced with him vpon our Church greene in a Morris ere now.

sp.speaker: Infor.
sp.p: Alas, alas, has forsaken thee?

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.p: He is now about to commit matrimoniall businesse with a young girle I wisse.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.l: 'Tis she. Ile haue a tricke to know it.
Blessings on you Shepheardesse,
Yet by this hand, you are no lesse,
You were in loue with a faire man,
Crost by a father, began
This Shepheards life, & russet weed,
Is it not the truth, I reed? ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Sir, are you a Fortune-teller?

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.l: No, I am foole, and yet I know
Something, though you thinke not so.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Doe you see all this here?

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: That and more in this table
sp.l: Lies your story: 'tis no fable,
Not a line within your hand,
But I easily vnderstand:
Your line of life is faire, hard by
Ascends that of prosperity,
But broken in the mid'st to th' Mount
Of Saturne here, which ill we count,
Ha, Triangle and Mercuriall line?
But Venus is no friend of thine.

sp.speaker: Infor.
sp.p: How now, Palmistry? beleeue him not.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.l: In your face your fate is wrote,
You lou'd a woman, she not you,
You know whether I say true,
Her name began with S. but shee,
Shall neuer be enioyd by thee,
Shees married now to one that's old,
But very rich: your fortune's told.

sp.speaker: Infor.
sp.p: Beshrew me he has cunning.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: Doe you beleeue him sir?

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.p: Beleeue him? nay, you may beleeue him, he's abomination cunning man, he told me my fortune as right as if he had beene in my belly.

sp.speaker: Shep.
sp.p: Does thy fortune lie in thy belly then, Sweet-heart?

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.p: Partly, sir, as other womens fortunes doe.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.l: Damsell, you haue yet a fate
Will make you wonder more thereat,
By collection, I dare proue,
That his name, whom you did loue,
Began with G. but 'tis too true,
He hath slaine himselfe for you.
sp.p: Felice, come againe, doe not beleeue me, I told thee false, I did but trie to gaine a knowledge of thee: thy starres owe thee more happinesse, Felice, looke vp, see thy friend aliue, I am Gasparo. Foot, I ha made faire worke.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.l: Ha, 'tis Gasparo.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.l: Haue I found thee, O wench, thou wert vniust,
Too much vniust, thus to absent thy selfe
From Gasparo, thy cruell father since
Hath wept enough to wash away his error.
Fates, I doe thanke you, for this blest direction.
But Infortunio, I am sorry now,
I read the truth of thy vnhappinesse,
It is too true, Selina is beyond
Your spheare of hope, pardon, worthy sir,
The shape I tooke, was not to mocke your fortunes,
But trie mine owne. And haue I found the wench?

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.p: Oh, no, no, your suite is in vaine, hands off, Shepheards.

sp.speaker: 1. Shep.
sp.p: I will make thee amends and marry, prethee sweet Mopsa, beautifull Mopsa.

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.p: Beauty! I doe confesse I haue reasonable beauty, for blacke and white, for all other colours are but compounded of them: but the truth is, I cannot so soone forget my old loue; though he hath prou'd false vnto me, Mopsa will proue true vnto him: oh, and it were not for shame, now I would die for loue.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Be not deiected, sir, you haue a fate
Doth smile vpon you, I haue a little skill.
In that this Gentleman seem'd to haue some knowledge,
I must needs crosse his iudgement, and pronounce
You are more happy.

lg.l: Let not ought your soule annoy,
You that virgin shall enioy,
That you first lou'd, who doth waite
To make your wishes fortunate,
And ere Sun twice declines to West,
You may be with marriage blest.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.l: The boy is mad.

sp.speaker: Infor.
sp.l: Doe not vndoe, sweet boy, the benefit
Thou hast already done me, thou dost vtter impossibilities.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: Then with one Argument I can easily
Take off your wonders, looke on thy Selina,
That on the wedding morne, forsooke Rufaldo,
Touch'd with a sense of thy indignities,
Thus to obscure me from all curious search
And inquisition, but not hoping euer
To be made thine, now if true loue maintaine
The opinion you pretend, thus in your armes
I powre my selfe.

sp.speaker: Infor.
sp.l: It is Selina. Oh, I am rent in pieces
With ioy and wonder.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.l: Harke you, sir, doe not beleeue him,
Let not passion make you a mockery.
sp.p: Is not Selina married to Rufaldo? then am I goose-giblet: I should haue bin at Church with 'em, but for a crotchet that I had in my pate all the morning: I spake with her father yesterday, and from his mouth I heard, Selina was very well, I thinke I doe not dreame, indeed now I call to memory, hee said Selina was mist two or three houres ath' wedding morne; some figarie, I know not what: and Antonio, as I supposed, gone in quest of her, not heard of since: but Selina is sure Rufaldoes wife, or some Deuill in her likenesse has abused them all with credulity. This is true, sir, therefore be not easie, doe not deserue more pitty, this boy is mad, a iuggling boy.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: Shall I not be beleeued then for my selfe? am I refused now?

sp.speaker: Inf.
sp.p: It cannot be she: troth boy, thy conceit tooke me at first with much credulity: but here's our natures weaknesse, apt to credit what wee affect: were there not too much against it, thou mightst deceiue me: oh no, Infortunio is giuen vp, lost to all felicity.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: Since then you put me, sir, to proue my selfe, let me not be lost, I will not call you what I desire, nor name you sister: giue me leaue to finde my selfe, I know not where I am yet: my brother Antonio gon? what fury hath assum'd Selina's shape?

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: Come, put on a mans spirit, Mopsa.

sp.speaker: Gor.
sp.p: Well, sir, in regard you are so Exit cum Inf. & Fel portunate, although I haue forsworne marriage, if you desist constant, you may chance to haue a licke at my Maydenhead.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: I haue it, my Brother's lost:
Ile send a shepheard in Antonio's name,
To inuite my Father hither, and that Incubus.
I vow not to forsake these Plaines, till I
Possesse my selfe, or be reiected quite,
Suspend thy passions then awhile, Selina,
To morrow is the Shepheards Holiday,
Which they solemnize with rurall pleasures,
'Twill draw them sooner: ha, are they gone?
I will not leaue 'em, with this thread I shall
Tread o're the Labyrinth, and discouer all.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Antonio slaine? haplesse Cornelio,
My hopes were treasur'd vp in him, the staffe
And comfort of my age, and is he gone?

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Hast sent for Bubulcus?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I haue,
Father, let not too much passion soyle that temper
Hath beene obseru'd in old Cornelio.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Why, was not he thy Brother? canst thou
Thou hast so little share in yong Antonio,
That thou darest speake of comfort?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Sir, on my life Antonio is not dead.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: No, no, 'tis impossible.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Bubulcus, on my soule's a very coward,
And durst as well attempt to take a prey
Out of a Tygers iawes, as see a sword
With patience bent against him.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: But cowards in despaire proue desperate, and most vnhappy.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: A my conscience I could beate him into a mouse-hole.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: Nay, I could beate him, and I am sure you can beate me, woo'd I were well rid of you: 'tis a double misery to be abus'd, and dare not speake out.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Here's Bubulcus.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Not guilty, not guilty, and please your Worships, let me not be hang'd for a lie of mine owne making: 'tis well knowne I am a stinking coward: not guilty, I beseech you; I neuer drew sword in anger in my life: if you hang me, you vndoe me for euer.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Looke you, sir, 'tis cleare.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: My conscience is as cleare as Christall: not guilty, my Lord, I beseech you—

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Didst not thou kill Antonio then?

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Let me be hang'd if I did.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Stay, he'le confesse.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: I confesse I told a lie, thinking to haue got some credit: but if euer I saw Antonio, since he gaue me two or three kicks, which I deseru'd well enough, broyle me ath' coales. Mercy, oh mercy: doe not cast me away vpon the Hangman now, in the pride of my youth: not guilty, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Howsoeuer feare of death possesse him so, I see the murther in his eyes.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: My eyes? woo'd they were out then: doe you see murther in my eyes? are my eyes blood-shot?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: His very hand doth shew a guiltinesse, looke how it trembles.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: The feare of hanging hath put my whole body into palsey: My hands guilty? I can wash my hands cleane of it, I neuer kild a Fly. By this hand, not guilty.

sp.speaker: Shep.
sp.p: Which is Cornelio?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: This: what's the matter? what makes this Shepheard here?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: I am Cornelio: is it with me thou woo'dst?

sp.speaker: Shep.
sp.l: If your name Cornelio be,
Contentment and felicity
I bring you: I am sent from one
That doth call himselfe your sonne,
Yong Antonio, who thus low
Would beg your blessing, prayes that no
Affliction too much you dismay
For his absence, bad me say,
If you daine suspend your care,
A few houres, and repaire
Vnto the place of Shepheards by,
To grace their pleasures with your eye,
Antonio will himselfe declare,
Faithfully what causes were
Of his absence, and requite
These dolours with a fresh delight:
And so farewell. This is all:
Back againe I heare them call.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Oh stay awhile.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: He's gon, sir: did I not tell you, Antonio was not dead? but this is strange.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Doe I not dreame?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Antonio among the Shepheards? if he be there, I am drest Ifaith: By any meanes, goe sir.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Is Antonio aliue againe?

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: Yes verily, aliue againe, let not the Hangman fright away your wits any longer.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: I hope I shall choose my owne Gallowes then. Hillaria, you would not beleeue me: did I looke as I had kild any body? now I hope you will hold me for an innocent hereafter.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Babulcus, pray' let vs haue your company,
It doth concerne your freedome. Antonio liuing?
Rufaldo, let vs make a merry day on't,
If it be true. If? I doe sinne against
Discretion to distrust it. O my starres,
I doe acquit you all your iniuries,
If you possesse me of Antonio.
Neuer did man to blisse more willing goe.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: I am glad I am reprieu'd: come Hillaria.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: 'Twere pretty if Antonio bee multiplied: here's tricks indeed, I am resolu'd to see what will the end of this confusion be.

sp.speaker: Ien.
sp.p: Neuer was Ienkin in such Wildernesse, her haue walked and trauelled creat deale of miles in these Woods: but her can finde no end nor euasions, looke you: her haue read in Histories, and Relations, and Kernicles, very famous Knights, and praue Sentilmen of valours and shiualries haue beene enchaunted, looke you, in Castles and very strange dwellings, and Towers, and solitary places, now was haue creat feares and suspicions, lest Ienkin was fallen into some Wisheries and Coniurations, and was inchaunted, blesse vs awle in these Desarts and Wildernesses for her valours and magnanimities.

sp.speaker: Ioc.
sp.p: So ho, ho, Master Ienkin.

sp.speaker: Ien.
sp.p: It is our Pages agen. Iocarello, where haue you beene? you are very tilligent Poyes, to lose your Master thus.

sp.speaker: Ioc.
sp.p: I was lost my selfe, had not a Shepheard by chance found me, and carried me into his house vnder the ground, where with a great many of Shepheardesses we sate vp all night in making Garlands for some shew and pastimes to be done this day, which they call their Festiuall: pray', sir, since we haue run a wildgoose chase so long, let's stay one day to see these sports and dancings.

sp.speaker: Ien.
sp.p:
Sports and dances, say you? take pleasures and delectations in dances? Very well, Ienkin was knaw how to dance her selfe, was pred in awle Sentilmans qualities,
looke you, her will make no peregrinations backe till awle be done, and it may bee, was shake her legs in capers too, looke you now.

div.stage: Enter Cornelio, Rufaldo, Antonio, Bubulcus, Hillaria.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.p: Master Ienkin, you are well met in these parts, I perceiue you are early this morning, to partake the pastimes of our Shepheards.

sp.speaker: Ien.
sp.p: Good tayes and salutations, and cret deale of felities come to awle your vrships.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Sir, my name is Master Bubulcus, and I am as good a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Ien.
sp.p: As who pray you? doo you make comparisons?

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: I doe embrace your familiarities, and remaine your truest worme.

sp.speaker: Ien.
sp.p: Not too much wormes, nor familiarities pray you: ha Pages, here is Selinaes in her owne apparels and vestiments, awle was very true as our Countrey-woman Ecchoes was make reports: Selina was gone back agen: very well: Mistris Selina's was very full of ioyes and exhillarations, to see you in these places, you knaw how greatly and ardently Ienkin was taken with your peauties, and pulchritudes, cret while agoe: pray' when did you make returnes out of these woods? Ienkin had knowledge, and saw you in your Shepheard apparels, and was make ambulations after you hither, out of meere amors and affections as her was true Sentilman.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I make returne out of these woods? I entred them but now.

sp.speaker: Ien.
sp.p: Well, you desire not to haue things declared, and puplished, her was keepe awle silences.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Vpon my life you are mistaken quite in this, Master Ienkin.

sp.speaker: Ien.
sp.p: Oh, pray you make not Ienkin ridicles, and derisions, looke you, shall heare no more of that matters, call you only to memories you promised loues to Ienkin, pray you in matrimonies creat while agoe.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
I deny not that, sir, but I know not why you haue
long neglected me, and I am now married to Rufaldo.

sp.speaker: Ien.
sp.p: Rufaldoes? hit is not possible.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Father, hee sayes it is impossible Selina should bee your wife.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: How, not my wife? I would faine see that.

sp.speaker: Ien.
sp.p: Is Selina your wifes in truths and verities pray you?

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: Doe you make question? My wife? I thinke there is some reason, shee is my very deare wife, I will assure you sir.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: He has got a boy by this time.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: A boy? well, I haue got something, a pox a your fingers. How saist? is not something, done Sweet-heart?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Yes, in my conscience something is done.

sp.speaker: Ien.
sp.p: Ienkin was neuer awle his dayes haue such iniuries and contumelies put vpon her: was euer Sentilman thus abused? haue her made repetitions and genealogies of her plood, for no matrimonies? Ienkin has peat the pushes, and Rufaldoes has get the pirds. Hum! her loue not to make quarrels & prabbles, but Ienkin could fight with any podies in the whole vrld, awle weapons, from the long Pikes to the Welsh-hookes, looke you now, no matrimonies? her Welsh-blood is vp, looke you.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Master Bubulcus.

sp.speaker: Ien.
sp.p: Master Blew-pottles, haue you any stomakes or appetites to haue any plowes or knogs vpon your costards, looke you?

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: No great stomack at this time, sir, I thanke you: alas, I haue 'em euery day, they are no nouelties with me.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Come, Master Ienkin, I now perceiue you lou'd my daughter, if you had acquainted me in time, I should not haue beene vnwilling to haue cald you sonne, but since 'tis too late, let your wisedome checke impatience: I know you are of a noble temper, howsoeuer passion may a little cloud your vertues, lets be all friends I pray.

sp.speaker: Ien.
sp.p: Here is very cood honest words, yes, looke you, Ienkin is in awle amities and friendships, but—

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p:
Oh, no more shooting at that but: harke, I heare
the Shepheards musicke, and voyce too, lets sit downe I pray, Antonio keepe thy word.

div.stage: Musicke. Enter Shepheards and Shepheardesses with garlands.

lg.l: Wood-men Shepheards, come away,
This is Pans great holy-day,
Throw off cares,
With your heauen aspiring aires
Helpe vs to sing
While valleyes with your Ecchoes ring.
Nymphes that dwell within these groues,
Leaue your Arbours, bring your loues,
gather poesies,
Crowne your golden haire with Roses,
As you passe
Foote like Fayries on the grasse.
Ioy drowne our bowers, Philomell,
Leaue of Tereus rape to tell,
Let trees dance,
As they at Thracian Lire did once,
Mountaines play,
This is the Shepheards holiday.

div.stage: Dance. The song ended, Enter a maske of Satyres &c. and dance. Enter a Shepheardesse with a white rod.

sp.speaker: 1. Shep.
sp.l: Post hence Satyres and giue way,
For fairer soules to grace the day,
And this presence, whip the aire
With new rauishings, hence with care,
By the forelocke hold Time fast,
Lest occasion slip too fast
Away from vs, ioyes here distill.
Pleasures all your bosomes fill.

div.stage: Enter Infortunio, Selina, Gasparo, Felice, Gorgon, Shepheard.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: Faire Nymph, vouchsafe the honor to dance with me.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Troth, sir, I cannot dance.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: We know you are Selina.

sp.speaker: Infor.
sp.p: Your hand, fairest.

sp.speaker: 1. Shep.
sp.p: Disdaine not, gentle sir.

sp.speaker: Ien.
sp.p: Pible pables, with awle her hearts, looke you.

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.p: Noble sir.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Faire Lady, at your seruice.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: I will not change.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Nor I.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Which is Antonio?

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: It will breake out anon.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: You are a thiefe.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Ha?

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: You haue robd Selina.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Then Ile make restitution, what are you?

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: Antonio.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: The Deuill you are! faith, deale honestly with me, and Ile be true to thee: who art?

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: I am Selina by my hopes of heauen.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Ha, sister then!

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: I haue no brother but Antonio.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: And I am he. Oh happinesse!

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: If thou beest Antonio, what made thee assume my habit?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Of that anon. Liues Infortunio?

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: Hees here, and with him Gasparo and my sister the lost Felice.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I am rauisht with this wonder.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: Keepe your face constant: the Musicke calls.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Ha, what meanes this?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Selina.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Your blessing, sir, we are your children.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Who's this?

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.p: I am Selina, sir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: And I am Antonio.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Amazement: thou Antonio? he Selina?

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: Ha, how's this, my wife become a man? I confesse she plaid the man with me.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: But who is this?

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.l: I am Felice, sir, your long lost Daughter,
Found out by Gasparo, vnto whom my vowes
In Heauen were long since sacred, and I beg
Once more he may be mine.

sp.speaker: Sel.
sp.l: As I to be possest
By Infortunio here.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Stay children, stay: take heed, you doe not know
What strength of ioy my fainting age can beare:
You fall in too full showres, like swelling Nile
These comforts will exceed the narrow bankes
Of my poore frailty: rise, enioy your wishes,
And my blessings be multiplyed vpon you. Ha!
Rufaldo, here's Felice my lost Girle,
Take her, take her, Gasparo. Selina,
Art not thou Rufaldo's Wife?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: No, sir, I ventured that, he knowes me well,
Hillaria and I were bed fellowes, at his request.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: How? Hillaria and you bedfellowes? I'de laugh at that.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: I am abus'd, disgrac'd, vndone.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Nay, Rufaldo.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Why then, it seemes you were Antonio, that I kild so, and you haue, as a man should say, line with Hillaria beforehand.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I am not behind hand.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Nay, and you haue tickled her before and behind, tickle her all ouer for Bubulcus.

sp.speaker: Ien.
sp.p: Harke you, is there another Selina's? blesse vs awle, here is very praue loue-trickes, looke you.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: Blessing on him: why he hath made Stockfish on me, hee has beaten away all my inclination to giue my blessing.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Come, vpon recollection, you must make it a bargaine: they haue, it seemes, bought and sold already, 'tis past recouery, he shall be worthy of her.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Sir, that you may with more alacrity let fall your blessings: know, our bloods are pure, Antonio and your Daughter are as chaste from any sinfull act, as when wee were first mantled after birth.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: Ha, saist so?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: 'Twas none of my fault, I am sure.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: Then my blessings to you: come, y'are both my Children.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.p: Amen, and mine: Why I am rapt beyond my selfe with ioyes. Infortunio, Fate hath effected that I beg'd of Heauen in many prayers for you, oh my blisses.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: So, so, I am guld, my house taken o're my head?

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.p: Sir, you know who I am, I am yet walking Terra incognita, I haue a great minde to Bubulcus, you know what I haue suffered for him, and so forth.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: Let me alone, so, so: then pleasures runne with a streame vpon vs, but if we shall make a full day on't, here's one more to meet with her match, this poore Virgin hath beene long in loue with Bubulcus: troth, sir, looke vpon her at length pittifully complayning: alas good soule, be honest at length: prethee doe, and marry her, you know what has past betweene you, 'tis a handsome Wench.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Vmh, I doe remember she was in loue with mee, and so was twenty more: what's that to me? Alas, would you haue me descend so low?

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.p: Oh, sir, you sung another song in my Mothers Dairy, when we sate vp all night together, and had a Sack posset.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: I doe remember such a thing, but what's that? Ile take't vpon me.

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.p: I beseech you, Gentlemen, speake for mee, for I will haue him, I am asham'd to shew my reasons.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Very small ones: away you durty queane.

sp.speaker: Inf.
sp.p: What, has he got thee with child?

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.p: More then that, sir.

sp.speaker: Fel.
sp.p: Has he had any Bastards?

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.p: Indeed Mistris, Ile tell you; hee hath begot three children of my body.

sp.speaker: Inf.
sp.p: Fie vpon't, no lesse then three Bastards.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: How? nay, she lies falsly, I got but two, so many I will acknowledge, because they shall not doubt my sufficiency, had I any more then two? speake you lying whore

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: Sir, I tender your credit, there is but two waies either you must marry her, or giue her a piece of money that's the easiest way, she is poore: for your reputation—

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: What doe you thinke will content the Whore?

sp.speaker: Ien.
sp.p: Harke you, best for you, make some satisfactions to this Sentilwoman, or Senkin was learne you more honesties and behauiours towards these vmans, warrant you Master blew pottles.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: A matter of twenty or thirty pieces, you can spare them.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: You Strumpet, here's twenty pieces for you: doe you heare? keepe well the boyes then: but you shal sweare, before these Gentlemen, you will neuer claime marriage: there, be an honest woman hereafter.

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.p: Yes, beare witnesse, Gentlemen, I doe accept his wise beneuolence, and will neuer trouble him with marriage— while Gorgon liues.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Gorgon?

sp.speaker: Gorg.
sp.p: Your seruant, and your pardons: nay, Gorgon has had his deuices and vagabunduloes as well as the best on yee: giue you all ioy, I wish you wit, sir.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: I am foold of all sides, was I borne a foole?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Ien.
sp.p: Stay you, Master double colours, there bee more fooles in the busines as your selfe: well Ienkin, were euen best make shurneyes back into her owne Countreyes, and neuer put credits or conferences in any womans in the whole vrld: they all lie and coozen, and make derisions out awle measures.

sp.speaker: Inf.
sp.l: Nay, nay, Gentlemen, let's all together
Wee'le drowne all discontents this day with wine.
Let's take vp all our Fates then, and proclaime
This day new Festiuals in Hymens name.

sp.speaker: Bub.
sp.p: Stay a little, and Ile along with you. Since I haue mist my Wench, Ile aske these Gentlemens good wils to a second match, in stead of an Epilogue.

sp.speaker: Gor.
sp.p: Why, how now? what, are you mad? will you speake the Epilogue? though you haue plaid a foole in the Play, you will not show your selfe an Asse before all this company. The Epilogue? I hope I am the wiser ath' two, and the better read in complement.

sp.speaker: Ien.
sp.p: Harke you, Master double-colours, and you goody Gorgons, here is one wiser, Asses you both, to pronounce the Epilogue, warrant you, and one, that knawes— to speake in as good English, Gentlemen, now sans Complement.

div.l: Our Loue-trickes haue beene shewne, and we attend
To know if your acceptance crowne the end,
The world is full of trickes, but it will be
To these of 〈…〉 contentment dwell
On you we 〈…〉 Play Thieves well,
Which 〈…〉 call, that we might proue
〈…〉 your loue.
